description:
Tips:

$30 for 2 pizza's (12 inch)
Full Harvest (vegetarian)
Chicken Alfredo (mushroom, bacon, chicken, cream sauce)

----------------------------------------------------------------

I would agree that the pizza here is a bit messy because the crust under the pizza can get a bit soft and the toppings fall right off. I would suggest being careful when eating it or just eating it with a fork and knife!
author: Alice H.

description:
I got a shrimp salad sandwich through Mealpal. They had it ready when I arrived. The sandwich tasted great, but I wouldn't want to pay the normal $13.35 price for it.
I've been here for happy hour before. $1 off draught beer! 
Here's a tip: Happy Hour here ends at 5:00. Leave work a few minutes early and get your order in right away to get the $1 off deal.
author: Marvin M.

description:
My team booked a reservation here the day before for a work lunch through Yelp. Since we had limited time it was really nice to be able to walk in and leave within an hour. Also with multiple dietary considerations there were plenty of options. Service was friendly and for a decent option near the office (when they are paying) I would recommend this place. Although based on other reviews sounds like happy hour is the better time to visit. 

With rent as high as it is I can understand why they would try to cram as many diners in here as possible. But it was a bit awkward to be seated so close to the table next to us and to have to squeeze in and out.

I ordered the Sutro pizza, while big enough for two meals for me, I felt like $18 for a pizza that was just okay was a bit much. The potatoes added nothing to the flavor, I actually preferred it without them and I would have liked more pesto sauce on the pizza. Mine also came out with a ton of flour on the plate so it was a really messy and a bit bland.
author: Tarah P.

description:
Archive is an amazing spot for HH in the city. I came on a Friday around 5pm, and we got seated immediately!

Their drinks are SO affordable - I got the Rose Sangria for $6, since all drinks were $2 off during HH. Really great pricing for the Financial District. 

For food, my friend and I ordered the truffle orzo mac n' cheese (because we deserve it) and the Lucas pizza. Both were totally delicious!

I highly recommend coming to Archive for happy hour. Cool interior, good food, and good service!
author: Monica H.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner last night and was very impressed with both the service and the food. The restaurant decor and ambience is perfect for a few drinks after work with colleagues or a dinner date. The space is a little tight, so probably not preferable for big groups, but for the 4 of us it was perfect. I had the beet salad which I added chicken to. The portion was perfect for a main or a shared starter. The pricing is not too bad especially for being in downtown SF, the bill came to roughly $100 for the 4 of us and we all left with full happy bellies.
author: Sarah-Jade S.

description:
In a world full of mediocre fast casual restaurants, Archive is a welcome blast to the past when people actually gave a damn about lunch. No Chipotle analogues that rip you through and hand you a $15 grain bowl, just a good, old fashioned sit down lunch with lots of options for all levels of dieters. From gluten free to vegan to caveman-like carnivorous diners, there's something for all on the list.

I've been here several times at this point, and their salads are generally what I gravitate towards. The chef's and cobb salads pack a punch, and you'll legitimately walk away full after a plate of leafy greens and chunks of meat. Their pizzas and sandwiches are also quality, and depending on the type of place you work, it's always nice to have an option for a glass of vino.

Reservations are recommended as they do get pretty packed around noon.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Such a fun place for a happy hour! Amazing wings and gorgeous cheese plate rounded out with a cold beer has made for a great start to the evening.
author: Karen A.

description: One of my go-to places when meeting friends for lunch - nice ambience, fast service and great pizzas. As a meat lover, my favorite is the Coit - andouille sausage, applewood smoked bacon and roasted chicken!
author: Tak K.

description: The staff was friendly, replaced an order that was incorrectly made promptly without complaint, and the food was very good.  There were 9 people in my party, and we were in and out in 75 minutes.  The ghost chili sausage pizza was amazing, not TOO hot and with top notch flavor.  Great place for small to medium size groups, I don't think they'd be able to sit a party much larger than ours very comfortably.
author: Matt U.

description: Made a reservation prior and was seated right away for a party of 5, had a great overall experience. Ordered the turkey club with bacon and was very pleased with how filling it was, also it comes on delicious sourdough bread. The mint lemonade wasn't as sweet as I would have liked but the staff was friendly and attentive so I would definitely go back.
author: LeVar H.

description:
Cool decor with the open brick walls and high ceilings on the smallish side. I remember going here when they first opened a few years. They have stayed consistently good.

Good service...nice to see good teamwork in action. The truffle mushroom garlic pizza is great and so is the pulled pork sandwich.
author: Sunil R.

description: I probably had half a pizza, Archive is so good. We did carry out and the pizzas were just as good if you dined in. I'm a deep dish pizza lover but I can't say enough good things about this thin crust pizza. Flavorful, filling and so delicious. I love the layout and design off the pizza with each slice getting just enough of the toppings. I even ate the crust! Superb job Archive, well done. For lunch and dinner, you have to stop by anytime you're in San Francisco. This little treasure is a nice surprise and great representation of what good Cali pizza tastes like.
author: Liz B.

description: Pizza is bland despite the truffle oil and goat cheese. Host failed to advise us about the area in which we were seated would be overrun by happy hour. Had to chase down bartender for check. Wish I liked it because it is convenient to work, but will not go again.
author: Shelby S.

description:
BYOR...bring your own ranch sauce to dip. If you're like me, and you must dip your pizza in ranch then be prepared to bring your own because they do not have ranch here. I repeat, they do not have ranch here. But they do have a house Gorgonzola cream dressing. It will do, but not quite the same.

Had the Coit and the 1906. I liked the Coit better since I'm partial to BBQ sauce. Crust is thin and crispy
author: Kat D.

description: My favorite pizza place in the city! Their margarita pizza is my favorite guilty pleasure. A little pricey, but well worth the money. It gets packed during peak lunch hours, so if you can go a little before or after you'll save yourself some time.
author: M K.

description:
Impressed by place and menu.

Great atmosphere for date night and for a little corporate party. Food and drinks are totally like in the menu. Fully recommend this place!

Tasty pizza with great variety of fillings, large selection of drinks, especially beers. 

Great music and cozy chairs. So, I would definitely recomend this place for alomst any ocastion!
author: Anna K.

description: This place always looks packed from the outside, and sure enough, when I actually ate here, it was full. My SO and I got bar seats, but it didn't feel terribly cramped despite the crowded atmosphere. They have a decent beer selection - I got a fruity gose. For dinner I had the beet salad and my SO had the Hearst pizza. The salad was a lovely combination of beets, quinoa, arugula, and goat cheese with the surprisingly lovely addition of grapes. And it was the perfect size too. My SO thoroughly endorsed the pizza. The service was so-so: I consistently had to yell over the dull roar of chatter in the tiny space to get the bartender's attention. But even so, that seemed to be a result of the crowd in the restaurant, not the actual quality of service. Overall, this is a solid spot for a casual dinner and drinks.
author: Megan B.

description:
In town for business and dropped in here for lunch with my kids. The decor was nice, there was a great vibe, and our server super friendly. In fact, the friendly server is what enticed us to come in and sit down.

We ordered a simple half cheese, half pepperoni pizza, a couple of salads, and a sandwich. The salads were superb (highly recommend both the beet/frisee and the Caesar), the turkey club was very good, and the pizza was good as well. There was, however, a misunderstanding in the kitchen, and instead of delivering what we ordered: a pizza that was half cheese only and half pepperoni and cheese, the cook made a full pepperoni, with half with cheese on it and half without. Seems like a small thing, but a pizza without cheese on it is a hard sell to most people, especially to a tweenager. The server immediately recognized the mistake and offered to correct it but we ultimately decided it was less of a hassle for everyone to just eat what we had and leave the part of the pizza that was incorrectly made. 

When I got the bill, I realized we'd been charged full price for what was essentially a mistake. I asked our server to modify the bill and maybe only charge us half price for the incorrectly made pizza. He was totally amenable to that (and should have thought of/offered that himself). He came back and said "This is all he would do" referring to the owner, who was on site that day. The owner apparently approved discounting the pizza by something like $5, which is better than nothing, but from a service standpoint, kind of odd. When your kitchen goofs and a guest is nice enough to not make you go through the trouble of remaking something and wasting incorrectly prepared food, perhaps the least you can do is charge them half price as a thank you. 

All in all, the food was good, our server was great, and the ambiance here was great. The service, in the form of that extended by the owner, could be a better. And to be clear, it's not at all about the money -- it's about good business practices and a customer-centric mindset.
author: Shelly K.

description:
Love, love, LOVE this place. My friend and I usually come here to celebrate a special occasion after work (happy hour!) but it's typically packed. However, the staff are super accommodating and even if a table says reserved, it could be that they were reserving for walk-ins. I've gotten lucky the last 3 times, for sure!
Must-gets: Their happy hour sangrias are ~25 and so worth. My friend and I usually have 3 glasses each. 
- Cheese Board & Local Charcuterie are bomb if you don't want to stuff yourself too much. 
- For Pizzas, the Coit and Hearst are my faves - just enough if you want to try this place out but also gives you insight to some great tastes the restaurant has to offer. 
- If you'd like to lighten it up, their caesar salad is good n' light!
author: Julia T.

description:
Good spot for happy hour weekdays between 3-6 pm but it gets crowded so come early. 

The menu is built for sharing with items like sliders, cheese plates, and pizza. We ordered the Moscone pizza pie which has salami, sausage, and olives as the main toppings. Great choice if you're looking for a meaty tasting slice. We also paired the pizza with the beet salad which brings a nice brightness and sweetness as a counterpoint. A mix of gold and red beets paired with grapes and goat cheese dressed with a sherry vinaigrette make for a nicely composed salad. 

Service is friendly but they get slammed. Still, Archive Bar & Kitchen is worth considering if you can find a spot after work.
author: Jon L.

description:
I'd had this spot scoped out for a while. The pizza was so hyped here, but it was sort of bland to me. I loved how everything came out piping hot though!

I shared the Hearst pizza (bacon, goat cheese, mushroom, and truffle oil) and the orzo truffle mac.

While I loved the large bacon pieces on the Hearst, the ingredients didn't really seem to meld together and the crust could have used a bit more salt (I rarely say this) and oil (also rarely say this) to pull everything together. The crust lacked crunch (also rarely say this) but wasn't quite doughy either. I'm sorry, I'm being like Goldilocks today. (Just checked reviews, looks like I'm not the only one with this opinion. Phew!)

I love orzo as a salad pasta, but I'm not sure it has the surface area to carry the cheese in a way that makes mac and cheese so delightful. I really loved that this was way too hot when it came out, though that did interfere with texture initially since the pasta was almost melted too and the cheese wasn't gooey as much as liquid. Good truffle flavor on this though.

For such a small restaurant, it was extremely loud, and I definitely had to project my voice at my dining companion seated one foot across from me. Actually, the table next to me was closer to me, and conversation was hard. Some elements to dampen the sound would be helpful! Good ambiance otherwise. I actually enjoyed Atlas Tap Room and their flatbread a bit more.
author: Nicole H.

description:
This is Nice little Bar and Restaurant. Was quite busy even on a Wednesday evening. They had a good list of wine and beers, though I didnt have any. 
Had the Bolinas pizza. This is a vegetarian pizza. It has cauliflower, romanesco, tomatoes, onions, eggplant puree and goat cheese. Though the ingredients sounded interesting, the pizza was pretty bland and I could mostly just tasted cheese. I dont think it was great value for money. The pizza cost almost $17.
I really liked their crust though. Might go back to try some other pizzas and some of the veg starters.
author: Umang D.

description: Disappointed. I ordered several things in advance for pick up to take to a lunch meeting. The menu online had a chef's salad, which was one of the items I ordered. When I showed up shortly before my meeting to pick up the food, I was told they did not have the chef's salad anymore. So I ordered something I thought was similar and added chicken (I was charged extra for the chicken). I was almost late for my meeting because I had to wait for them. Opened up the food at the meeting. Lo and behold, no chicken in the salad that I was charged extra for.
author: Annie L.

description:
This is a great spot to come by after work for a Happy Hour drink and light bite. They have quite a few signature cocktails that are discounted from 3-6pm as well as their house wines and beers. I'm a fan of their champagne options, though beware if you order the Blood & Roses note it is pretty sweet.

If memory serves me right, Happy Hour doesn't apply to their food menu but it's reasonably priced and not bad if you split with others. The few times I've been here the food hasn't disappointed and seems like it's intended to share: Margherita pizza, truffle Mac n Cheese, warm pretzel with honey mustard, dates, jalapeño and artichoke dip with chips. 

The inside can get pretty loud so if the weather is nice I'd recommend sitting outside and enjoy some fresh air and people watching! There's always a nice buzz on Mission Street during Happy Hour.
author: Mina T.

description:
Typical SoMa/FiDi bar with an array of shareable bites as well as pizzas. Not sure if they're worth the price tag, average around $17-$20 for a medium 6-slicer that could easily be devoured by a single hungry person. A beet salad will run you about $13, and be anything spectacular in flare, portion size, or taste. Maybe add an egg on top like the French do, and it'll be worth the $13. 

Funny cocktail names, think "Alternative Facts" and they serve them up in antique-shaped glassware. It's a little noisy during peak hours since the venue is slender and acoustics are a bit rustic, but good for a happy hour beer or drink if you're in the area.
author: Alison A.

description: Great place for after work in FiDi. Good food and drinks, and indoor and outdoor seating. Service was decent considering they were hosting a large work group in addition to the several other small parties seated. If there was a happy hour there wasn't a mention of it but items were still reasonably priced.
author: Maia M.

description:
Truffle Mac n' cheese. 

WITH BACON. 

I DIE!

I should end my review right here since all opinions are moot on whether or not this is the BEST dish at Archive. Well, there's the pizza, but nothing comes close to the unique orzo based, carb heavy, all American delectable treat highlighted with unctuous cheese sauce. DUDE! this is the stuff cheese addicts dream about their whole life. 

Swear it on my grandma's dead puppy's grave. 

Anyway, about those pizzas, they are fantastic. They are not in anyway, the absolute best in SF, but guess what? Archive isn't aiming for that. The love for pizza is evident in the careful, well thought out flavor combos such as the Cardona (artichoke hearts, sundried tomatoes, swiss chard, goat cheese in an alfredo sauce) or the Hearst (white truffle oil, lardon bacon, wild mushrooms, roasted garlic) If you're feeling basic, their pizza margherita is as basic as you can get, although I disagree with putting fresh tomatoes on this one. I prefer mine with a simple sauce, basil and melty mozz combo. Either way, the pizzas here are hand pulled and the thin crust serves well to soak up the alcohol after you've come from Novela two doors down.  

I didn't imbibe here, but saw a happy hour that can't be beat. With the busy foot traffic on the corner of 2nd and Mission, Archive lures in the Fidi crowd into it's cozy space with warm interiors. This building miraculously survived the 1906 earthquake and kept its original brick walls and steel beams. I'm a sucker for a bit of history and any vintage industrial spot. I'll definitely return soon!

If only for the truffle mac n cheese.
author: Janice C.

description:
Although this place can get loud, it's one of the best pizzas in SoMa. Sandwiches are not bad either, but definitely go for the pizza if you can. The Hearst pizza is simply amazing, it has huge chunks of bacon that are often cooked to perfection.

One thing that is sort of annoying about Archive is the fact that they're not open on weekends. It'd be a perfect spot for people living in SoMa since between 3rd and 1st on Mission there are not that many places open.
author: Antonio H.

description:
It's not super easy to find quality lunch options in this area, imo, but Archive should definitely be on your "solid" list. The staff have always been sound and I like the interior; it's not too packed in and the little outside seating is p pleasant in the lunchtime sun. 

Now: The pizza. If you're gf, the non-gluten crust is really well made. It's more thin-crust style, with a bit of crunch, and tastes great. I personally prefer normal, but I've colleagues who always go gf (fo taste and health reasons.) I've got awful teeth so sometimes the crust is a bit tough for me.

Dimaggio and beet salad are my go-to for sharing. You can't really go wrong with any of the pizzas, though!
author: Rowena H.

description: I tried their PASTRAMI & PEPPERS sandwich once through mealpal. It's unbelievably tasty. The pastrami is very juicy, and the picked pepper added into it made the sandwich very addictive. I wish I can order from them every day!
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
Oh Archive. I literally can't say enough good things about this place and the people who work there that make it great. I literally fell in love with this place and at this place. It's become like a second home. 

The lunch menu is absolutely perfect with crazy huge and changing salads, creative sandwiches that are big enough to split (but totally crushable) and their scrumptious pizzas. 

Their happy hour menu is noteworthy for the drinks but also those small bites... except there is nothing small about their sliders (except they are technically small burgers...). 

Dinner is just delicious. More appetizers and pizza and less salads and sandwiches and literally just everything is great. 

The ambience is cozy and murmured loud with warmth and the attention to detail is shown throughout the interior and with the beer selection and creative non liquor license cocktails and the fill your tummy wine. 

There is no bad place to sit in this small place because you'll kind of feel like you're sitting with everyone in there in the best way no matter where you are. 

I'm hooked.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Visited for a late lunch. Lunch crowd was just starting to thin. I sat at the (empty) bar and ordered a soda water with lime and a Margherita pizza with pepperoni from the bartender.

The pizza toppings and sauce were of excellent taste and quality. The crust was a good texture but *really* could have used a bit of salt to unlock the flavor. It was *thisclose* to being great.

Service from the bartender was just eh. I was dining by myself at an empty bar and he didn't attempt to make any conversation. At first he was making sangria, so I get that he was busy, but after that he was just trying to get one of the other servers to switch shifts with him and using his phone. 

But my bigger issue was that I ordered a soda water with lime, which he never refilled. I wasn't paying attention when he first gave me the glass of soda water, so I didn't see where it came from. When I got the bill I saw that he charged me $4 for a bottle of Pellegrino. I looked over to the side of his work area and saw a half-full bottle of Pellegrino and had to ask him, at that point, to please let me have the rest of my bottle of water. Kind of rubbed me the wrong way to end my meal.
author: Andie T.

description:
Finishing out our evening we were still a bit hungry and wanted to find a cool place near our hotel. I searched Yelp and decided on Archive. It was a comfortable little place with a nice bar area and seating along the walls. We had a nice server and she got our beers and took our pizza order soon after we sat down. Thin crust, wood fired pizza is my favourite and Archive delivered!
We ordered a "DiMaggio" and it was quite good. The base of the pie was a garden pesto spread and topped with Italian sausage, paquillo pepper, mushrooms, ricotta, and topped off with mozzarella goodness. Excellent job, Archive. 
If you're in San Fran, y'all should stop by and get your pizza fix.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Me and 2 friends were gonna go try Takoba but there was a party goin on over there so we walked over. It was superrrr busy and it was Thursday at like 6pm. The space is also really small and dark so definitely come early or def have a back up plan! 

I had pretty low expectations for this place but I was utterly surprised!! We shared some brussel sprouts and I got the Mozarrella Pizza & got 2 Sangria Rose's ;) The pizza was honestly nothing special but still pretty good. The dough was MHMM SCRUMPTIOUS and the cheese was damn good. The brussel sprouts were kinda weird and seem kinda undercooked and way too salty. The drinks seemed WEAKK at first but it's one of those things where it comes to hit you later. I would def come back to try some drinks!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Updated review-- I went back a few weeks later because I had a good experience there the first time, but this time it was the complete opposite. There were only 3 customers and about 5-6 employees. It took them about 50-55 minutes to bring us our food. I believe he was the boss but he told us that he burned the pizza and had to put a new one in. At this point, it was already frustrating because we had to wait even longer for the new pizza to cook. Yet, when we got our pizza it was still burnt. The tomatoes were still raw and uncooked. Took about 15-20 minutes to get our drinks while we waited for our pizza. We paid for the pizza. The owner should have taken the pizza off our bill or gave us a discounted price out of common courtesy and customer satisfaction. One of the worst experiences I've had in the city. This place is a hit or miss. Some days are better than others, but it's not worth the risk. We will not be returning. 


First review-- This place is so good! The pizza and salad was BOMB! I am definitely going back! I the bartender was friendly and sweet! Great place for lunch!
author: Cecile ..

description: Came in late to grab some pizza on the way back to my hotel. Delicious thin pizza with a nice crust. The pepperoni and sausage are really nice. I appreciated the quick service as well!
author: Christin J.

description:
For lunch or dinner, Archive never seems to disappoint. 

Right around the corner from work, my co-workers and I usually share a salad and a pizza. The salads are simple and satisfying, but the real menu winners are the pizzas. The Hearst pizza, with gluten-free crust and arugula added on top, will have you coming back every week. Just note that it includes whole garlic cloves, so make sure to bring gum if you're running to a meeting right afterwards!

The waiters are always accommodating to your preferences and truly understand the Bay Area habit of customizing everything on the menu. The seating can be limited, but if you go a little early, you can snag a seat and enjoy prompt and friendly service. For dinner, the wine list is great, making Archive a fun, casual spot to unwind after work as well.
author: Shira W.

description:
I stopped by with a group of 7 people on a Friday evening because every other place in SoMa was packed as expected. Surprisingly, they happened to have a table open with no wait. 

Service was friendly and reasonably attentive for a full house. They also have a pretty good beer/wine menu with average prices ($7-9/pint of beer). Nothing exceptionally impressive but wasn't underwhelming by any means. I would go back for happy hour next time most likely. 

I can't speak for the food since I didn't sample any while I was there, but it looked and smelled really good. The space also wasn't too loud, so if you are in a larger group not wanting to shout over the entire restaurant, this could be a good alternative to a bar situation. The restaurant itself is fairly small so I would say either get there during non-dinner time or opt for sitting at the window bar. This is your local let's-grab-a-drink-and-artisan-pizza spot that doesn't compromise ambience and service.
author: Catherine L.

description:
Got a pulled pork sandwich with fried onion and slaw, blown away by the attention to detail in the sandwich, loved the browned bun.

Everything around looked just as good

Walked in, helped within 5 minutes, quick turn around on food, a boon to financial district work lunches
author: Robin H.

description:
Great location with limited indoor seating and a couple tables outside. Coming on a Friday night the place was packed! 

Dennis the host was really friendly and accommodating. My friend got there earlier and was able to snag seats by the bar as we waited for a table. Their HH sadly was from 3-6pm, but lucky for me my friend got there early enough to order a few items. 

We ordered:
- Sangria Rose $25/pitcher HH price: my favorite of the two with light floral and fruity nuances. Very nice! Lauren was a great barista who knew how to make a good drink.
- Sangria Rioja $25/ pitcher HH price, this was more of a deep red wine taste. It tasted stronger.
- Orzo Mac and cheese $7 HH price. This was so good! Seriously whoever thought to use orzo instead of macaroni is a genius! It was delicious and the perfect mix of cheese to pasta. Must try
- HH sliders $4/ slider- nothing special I'd probably pass on this one next time
- Hearst Pizza $18- it was overly mushroommy, but if that is your thingy then great! 
- Coit pizza $17.50- my favorite if the two. Well made crust with fresh toppings. 

Overall, great place to hang out with friends with well made drinks and amazing orzo mac and cheese. The pizzas were good, but not amazing though for the ambiance and location this is a great place to meet up.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Warning: Severe food poisoning risk here. 

I had a lunch here because it is really close to my office. It turns out to be a disastrous decision. The pizza is expensive but no better than fast food delivery. Well, that is fine, at least not a big issue. The disaster started right after I finished my slices, even before I left the table. Pain started in my stomach, but I thought it was no big deal and managed to walk back to my office. Then it got from bad to worse. Vomiting and diarrhea, lying in bed for three days so far, I am still feeling sick. It is a clear symptom of food poisoning. It might not be the routine but just a bad luck, but I strongly recommend anybody to try their luck somewhere else. You can find many better and safer options on Mission. Don't make my mistake.
author: Zhiyuan S.

description: Nice albeit crowded space for drinks and a bite to eat after work. Great selection of artisan pizzas and salads. Gets a little loud due to the small space and everyone trying to talk over each other, but it fuels the intimate atmosphere.
author: Sheridan T.

description: Archive has the best pizza in FiDi hands down! My favorite is the Lucas pizza. Definitely recommend coming here for lunch or laid back dinner. They have beer and wine but the drinks aren't very strong. Check it out
author: Clare O.

description:
Stumbled upon this place by accident since another restaurant close by we wanted to try out was too busy.  Too hungry to wait, we decided to give this one a try!  It was pretty good! 

On a cold sf night, it's hard to want to sit outside but the waiter convinced us saying the pizza oven heat will warm us...didn't really believe him at first but it was true...as long as you sit on right side of patio as you walk in. 

What we ordered:
-Debated between a few pizzas but settled on the spicy one...I forget the name but 1906 or something like that. It was good and definitely a meat lover's dream although it disappointed on the spicy factor like the description suggested. 
-truffle mac and cheese orzo was different but delicious. Felt healthier than the typical mac and cheese but I'm sure they're equally as fatty, but so worth it. We also added bacon to ours! 
-drinks were pretty good and strong, we tried a few of the whisky and tart drinks...I forget the names but you can't really go wrong. Also shown in pics.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Narrow and simple brick layout bar with a couple of seatings outside for the outdoor preferred people, like me, when weather permits!

It's a convenient, above-the-notch place to grab bar bites and drinks, after working hours! 

Their white wine with a mint leaf, is the way to go for a refreshing drink. The sangria is a guaranteed win as well. They have draft beers for the beer lovers and it's great when a sport's game is on! 

Their prosciutto pizza that is topped with arugula, was complementing with drinks ordered up.  It is a good pizza entree to share.  Their mini sliders of pork and meatball, is doable for happy hour munching. 

Staff was nice and made sure we were taken care of.  

Limited seating when happy hour starts because it is a small place too!  However, a spot on bar to gather over drinks and bites!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Definitely a big fan of Archive. I come here every once in a while. Their pizza and salads are good for lunch. Their sandwiches are good for it you don't want to share. 

They don't do appetizers at lunch, only for dinner.
They also don't have any hot drinks (coffee / tea).

For dinner and happy hour, they have a good selection of appetizers to try, along with of course, their pizza and salads. 

They have a decent beer and wine selection to choose from.

Pretty standard pricing for the area.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
I was excited to try this place since it's down the street from my office, but I was pretty disappointed when I went. 

DiMaggio pizza- My friend and I agreed, the pizza was quite bland. I had to sprinkle crusted peppers and cheese to give it a kick. The pizza is definitely shareable. Between two gals, we still had 3 slices leftover.

Cheese Board- a must order! Everything on the board was great. The jam was amazing and I loved all three cheeses. 

They serve happy hour from 4-6pm. They offer $1 off draft beer, $2 off cocktails, and $7 for their house wine. The house wine wasn't the greatest. My friend couldn't even finish her glass. 

3 stars for the cheese board and service.
author: Annie N.

description:
I love this place! I've been here 3 few times now over the past 3 years, and it's consistently wonderful. It's a surprisingly small space, warm and welcoming with a few tables outside on the front patio. Simple menu filled with really beautiful salads and pizzas, all generous portions and really decent prices. And with gluten free crust available, of course. 

My favorite pizza is the "Hearst" which comes with goat cheese, mozzarella, bacon, truffle oil, roasted garlic cloves, and toooons of gorgeous earthy mushrooms. So amazing! I've also had the Lucas which boasts plenty of prosciutto, arugula, and thinly sliced apples -- a little sweet and savory perfection.

The wine and cocktail list is fantastic (and you're paying for quality here). Drinks are between $9 and
$15ish, so not too bad. Service is really kind and speedy as well. We let our waiter know we'd need to leave in sort of a rush, and they did a great job taking care of us and creating a really lovely experience despite our short  visit. Can't wait to come back for a longer, lounge-t visit.
author: Kendall S.

description:
Came to this place during lunch rush with a group of coworkers and was still able to get a seat. We made it right at noon though so we ended up grabbing a table outside. The place itself is quite small  but they have tons of bar and window stools if you're in a smaller group. 

Right from when we turned the corner we smelled the place. IT SMELLED SO GOOD. 

I ended up getting the Hearst Pizza ($18) with an egg (+$2) that I split with my coworker. At first I thought it was pretty small especially since I was sharing it but half was definitely enough. They don't skimp on the ingredients so the pizza was topped with loads of mushrooms and chunks of thick bacon pieces (YUM). The crust was thin and crispy, but still held up with all the toppings and egg. 

Other people ordered the Caesar Salad, Meatball Sub, and Chicken Sandwich and they all looked so tasty! The sandwiches came with a side of ruffle chips. All looked enough for two people as well. My friend said the sandwich bread pieces held up really well with all the sauces too. 

Service was decent - they always made sure my water cup was full, but sitting outside waiters were less accessible. They did make an effort to adjust the tables so that we had more table room.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Great pizza- super flavorful and unique. Also loved their salads and drink options. Friendly and fast service for lunch.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Archive is one of my favorite spots in the city. They offer different kinds of pizzas, salads, and drinks.

If you're craving for something light and filling at the same time, try the Lucas pizza. Made with prosciutto, ricotta, fresh mozzarella, gorgonzola, pink lady apple, garlic oil, onion, and arugula. The size of the pizza is the perfect amount for two people, it's about 4 slices each. My favorite part of the pizza is the pink lady apple. Not sure about you but this is the first pizza I've had with fruit. Also, try one of their house libations. I love the Mrs. Doubtfire - agave wine, lillet, fresh grapefruit, and grapefruit shrub. It's very fresh and it's a creeper. You'll start feeling a little tipsy half way through. Haha.

And if you're still hungry, order one of their salads or the truffle orzo Mac and cheese. Before 3pm, it's $9 but during happy hour it's $7!
author: Tina M.

description:
After walking around the SFMoMA for 2 hours, my friend and I were STARVING and looking for somewhere to grab a quick lunch. It was around 3pm, so a couple of the restaurants that we checked out first were already closed to set up for dinner. I browsed Yelp for a few mins and came across Archive. As soon as we saw "Wine Bar" in their description, we said "Yep!" and headed over. 

Their menu was PERFECT for what we were going for, plus they had happy hour going on at the time. We ordered mac & cheese off of the happy hour menu, as well as a couple of sangrias. The sangrias were yummy (and strong- or maybe that's just because we hadn't eaten since breakfast around 8am) and the mac & cheese was amazing! It was piping hot and had truffle oil on it- perfect for the cold and windy day!

We both ordered pizzas (the Hearst and I think Fall Harvest). I LOVED the Hearst, my friend preferred her fall harvest. The Hearst had goat cheese, more truffle oil, bacon, mushrooms, garlic, and I'm sure other goodies that I can't remember right now. The Fall Harvest had squash, pine nuts, basil and pomegranate seeds. Both had thin crusts and weren't too heavy, but still hit the spot.

It's the perfect way to top off a museum trip and I would definitely go back!
author: Katie A.

description:
TLDR: Good pizza and drinks, not super pricey despite being in the heart of downtown. Good location for American bar fare. 

- Great pizza options, and good for sharing as a meal between 2 people, so not as pricey as you might think 
- Good location 
- Slow service, even when it's not super crowded 
- Loved the strawberry mixed drinks, super refreshing.
author: Salim Z.

description: Making plans to leave the office for lunch when need to be back in an hour somewhat stresses me out. Not when Archive is around though! For 2 consecutive years, I've walked into to Archive, found a groovy  seating, and immediately helped. The atmosphere is cool yet cozy with big windows letting in the sunshine toward the street. Sitting at the bar isn't cramped at all and I actually prefer it! Okokokok... the menu makes you want to order at least the whole left side of it. The portion sizes make it easy to split a pie between 2 (mmmmmmaybe 3.) I'm not usually a pizza crust partaker but this pie is bomb.com from the nucleus onward. Everything tastes notably fresh and an afternoon beer is cute to boot to pair... Cheers to a 5 star lunch!
author: Sarah M.

description: I'm a vegetarian so I got the Bolinas Pizza which felt pretty normal when I ate it, but I found myself thinking about it in the days following. I would definitely recommend the Bolinas. It was yum. Keep in mind that this restaurant is on the pricier side. I think I spent around $20 and the portion size can be eaten by one person, or two if people are eating small portions. I will likely return for more.
author: Karishma M.

description:
Love the ambience of this place. We came for dinner, but I think it's more of a happy hour or drinks spot.

They serve some appetizers, but mostly pizza. We ordered a pizza based on Yelp reviews and it was tasty. If you compare it to other happy hour pizzas, it's fine, but if you are a real pizza connoisseur, then the crust and cheese are both lacking. 3 stars for the pizza.

What we loved though was the beet salad! That was really amazing! Sweet beets, green grapes, arugula and goat cheese gives just the right balance of sweet and tangy with a punch. 5 stars!!
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Usually a bit busy for happy hour so I have to go next door to Atlas but I was able to snag a table today. Great service and good food! I wish they offered more food options for happy hour though-- even a few bucks off the full sized pizzas would be appreciated. 

My cocktail--blood and roses-- looked good but had way too much aperol in it so it tasted like cough medicine. Also learned a fun tidbit from the bartender about what fermented whiskey and fermented vodka are. Pizza--DiMaggio-- was above average. Gets loud but there is outside seating as well as seating for larger groups. I saw some signs that said "reserved" on tables but not sure if they take reservations. 

Overall, it's a popular spot for happy hour in this area and I would recommend it!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
LOVE this restaurant. The concept, the food, the service. Perfect spot to grab dinner with friends, co-workers, significant other, etc. It is an old school library themed place, with high brick walls, vintage shelves of books behind the bar. 

Best of all they're known for their thin crust pizza.  

Hearst: mushrooms, mozzarella, truffle oil, and THICK slices of bacon... YUM! Seriously, you can't go wrong with this combo.

Lucas: prosciutto, arugula, gorgonzola, garlic oil, and slices of apples. Who knew apples would be so delicious on a pizza. It was like eating a salad in pizza form, so I felt less guilty eating 4 slices (: 

Can't for get about the pork belly sliders. A thick slice of pork belly, with fig jam and a slice of apply all between a black sesame bun. This isn't your average slider. It's sweet and savory on a whole different level. Plus, it's on the happy hour menu!
author: Rachelle Y.

description:
I was just in there twice today. The waiter probably recognizes me and hopefully the owner isn't gonna claim that my review is from a competitor and that it's a fake one. 

I ordered the Mission chicken sandwich from MealPal. First time it was bloody (ewww!) I went back and requested a new one. Waiter was apologetic. I didn't think it was a big deal. We all deserve a second chance and it wasn't his fault. Grabbed the new sandwich and back in the office. Guess what? 2nd one was also pink and hard to chew on. Seriously, MealPal is cheap, we know. But for most ppl, it's great cuz it saves a lot of time. My lunch break only has 40 mins. And thanks to Archive I had to be starving while attending a meeting. You'd assume businesses should hold their food to a high standard even if it's for MealPal. After all, it's a gateway to get more first time customers and hope they'll convert to frequent customers. But no, not this stinky restaurant. I cook often so I know the issue. They probably cook straight from when the chicken breasts are still frozen. So naturally outside is cooked, inside is inedible. For all I know, they probably sell these to MealPal customers cuz the chicken were about to expired (hence deeply hidden in freezer and hard to cook) Invest in a freaking thermometer now, will you?? Do you know how disgusting it is to have accidentally eaten raw chicken??
author: Britta C.

description:
I came here with a friend after work for happy hour. We arrived around 4:30pm so it was totally empty, and we were seated right away. The tables in the back are tiny, especially for the drinks and pizza that you could potentially order, but this gives Archive an intimate feel. Even when this place is packed, we could still have an audible conversation.

My friend and I ordered drinks, and we could not resist the selection of pizzas on the menu. The Lucas seemed most popular, so we got that. It sounded delicious, with prosciutto, apples, garlic oil, onion, arugula, and a variety of cheeses. The waiters in this place are also hilarious. They are friendly and love to joke around.

The pizza eventually arrived, but I was a little disappointed by its flavors. It seemed to have so many ingredients but no distinct taste. The cheese and prosciutto were overpowering, though I'm not sure what else I would have expected. I was full by the end, impressed that I ate so much pizza, but I was not totally satisfied.

Because this is conveniently located on 2nd & Mission, I would come here again for drinks and social plates, but I'll pass on the pizza.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
As a general rule, I don't eat a lot of pizza outside NYC because [insert snobbery about living in the land of great pizza].

That said, Archive's pies are not bad at all. We shared the DiMaggio, the Hearst, and the Sullivan (in order of best to worst in opinion) and they tasted good because of sausage, bacon, and goat cheese, respectively. 

I did leave the majority of the crust on the plate, because [insert more snobbery about pizza]. However, the toppings were of superb quality, and it is evident in the taste. The sauce in particular was nice, which I think is the major reason the red pie outshone the two whites. 

The fact that the mixed Archive Mixed Greens salad (Cucumber, Baby Heirloom Tomato, Pear, Feta, Spiced Nuts & House Vinaigrette) was wonderful (if a bit overdressed) leads me to believe their non-pizza offerings are worth a shot as well.

If I might offer one warning:

Beware the toilet, as it wasn't flushing when I used it, which would've been far more embarrassing if I had been experiencing explosive diarrhea at the time. Luckily for me and everyone in the restaurant, it was just regular, non-eruptive diarrhea (in no way related to Archive), which is no cause for concern. 

(Now that I'm reflecting on it, I actually don't feel good about having made a poop joke in a restaurant review. However, I think I will leave it here because there exists a person who will be at Archive at some point in the future feeling under the weather, and this information could potentially save them a lot of embarrassment. If that person is you, I don't need any sort of reward. I would prefer that you just pay it forward by offering up pertinent toilet information in all your subsequent Yelp reviews.)
author: Peter D.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner on a Friday.

The chocolate malt shake is only $5 and so delicious. Tastes like liquid ice cream, but not as thick and sweet. A must try! The shake might be a bit much for 1 person, but it was perfect for 2. 

We also ordered two pizzas to split.
coit -  Andouille Sausage, Applewood Smoked Bacon, Roasted Chicken, Smoked Mozzarella, Onions & BBQ Sauce
moscone - Seasoned Sausage, Pepperoni Black Olives, Mozzarella & Organic Tomato Sauce
The coit pizza was my favorite with the three kinds of meat and it had so much flavor.

Service was quick even though the place was completely packed.
author: Edward W.

description:
Great little place in the Financial District. Decor is nice, Service at the bar was great (ask for Esteban) . Caesar salad was delicious , pizza was good too.
We'll come back !
author: Amalia L.

description: Came here because I was 1. Craving pizza and 2. They have Gluten free crust. Pizza came out and I was surprised with the crust--so light, so fluffy, so...wait a minute. Is this gluten-free? No. It was definitely a gluten-FULL crust. The server immediately took it away. I would've been completely horrified if I had a severe intolerance or allergy to gluten. Luckily for me, I'm on a gluten-free diet by choice. They gave us our gluten-free pizza and gladly did not charge us for it. 3 stars for a good pizza and rectification of mistake. Hearst pizza is amazing, btw. Minus 2 stars for complete carelessness. If you have a severe gluten allergy- please double check that the pizza is gluten free before taking a bite.
author: Carmela A.

description:
Good location and service, decent beer list. Though their limited-editions were so limited, they were out of all of them, and one of the bottles I wanted had just been put in the frig so wasn't yet cold enough to serve.
Happy hour specials were meh. $13 sliders for $12! They were tasty. The pizza was bad. Like, not really pizza.
It's loud. Was hard to hear other people at a table for six.
author: Carl B.

description:
I used to pass by everyday and wonder what is that amazing smell? I knew I had to try this place out. It looks like a nice place to go for happy hour. There's a long bar area along an exposed brick wall. The tables on the opposite side are a little cramped though. 
I came here with a friend for lunch and we split a pizza. The size of the pizza would be enough for one very hungry person. It's not a bad price for lunch in this neighborhood.

Hearst ($17) - white truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, wild mushrooms & bacon:
The pizza has a nice thin crust loaded with toppings. The amount of mushrooms, truffle oil, and cheese made it pretty floppy. I'm not a fan of mushrooms, but I liked them on this pizza. The bacon is plentiful and comes in big chunks. It almost killed me a little watching my dining companion pick the bacon off of her slices. This is an excellent mushroom and cheese pizza.
It's not quite as wonderful as whatever the aroma is that floats out of this place in the afternoon. Maybe it's the smell of dough baking in the afternoon.
author: Joy W.

description:
Awesome place for drinks and wine. 
One thing you'll want to order for sure is their cheese platter with various nuts and cheeses. 
It's an excellent appetizer that will go along with a glass of wine. 

All of their appetizers are delicious. It can get crowded so make sure you go before the rush hour to grab a seat since this place isn't meant for a fast turn over rate.
author: Eric R.

description:
I tried the Moscone pizza. It was good, as was the service. Price was fair.

There's really not much more to say about this place -- it's an unpretentious, comfortable after-work hangout. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but the location is convenient to a huge chunk of SOMA offices.
author: Barack O.

description: Great service, great cocktails, we had a pretty good appetizer... Only giving for stars because they don't have a full bar. ;)
author: Ashleigh V.

description:
Came in for lunch and had the Cuban.  It was $14 with a side, pretty standard price for the area and was worth it.  Good sandwich overall but could use some extra mustard.  Sat at the bar and got really good service plus I could watch the open kitchen staff make the food.  The place was clean and the cooks moved quickly. 

I really liked the vibe there.  Cool decorations and kind of on the darker side but didn't seem that dark inside. They had a handful of tables outside the front door which were crowded and the inside was about half full.  The beer list was kind of small but had some interesting beers.  Looked like a standard cocktail list and liquor selections.

Solid four star place and would return for sure.
author: Scott M.

description:
Wow. This might just be my new favorite place to get lunch in the area! I'd love to return for dinner sometime, too, so I can order bubbly cocktails and wine and take my time.

My group arrived a little after 11 and were the first to arrive for lunch. It was packed by the time we left, so plan accordingly. If you're on a tight lunch schedule, let the server know and they will make sure to get that spread out to you all spiffy-like. 

When I first glimpsed the menu, I have to admit to feeling that typical vegan defeat. That "here I am all hungry, and I'm going to have to have a plain salad and pay the same as if I had ordered the salad with bacon and bleu cheese" kinda feeling. But. They *will* take care of you here if you mention your dietary restrictions. At first I think I just ordered one of the mushroom pizzas without cheese. And then our waiter started asking me awesome stuff like, "How do you feel about some arugula and olives on it as well?" Like he read my mind! Yes, yes, I love arugula on pizza and olives are totally my jam! 

The pizza arrived and it was all I could do to contain the joy I was feeling at the sight of it. It was loaded with greens and veggies. To be honest, this is the type of vegan pizza I prefer (to the junkier but still delicious kinds with Daiya). The crust is perfectly thin so you can do the NY fold and eat it like it deserves to be eaten.

Look at reviewer Kendall S' photo of the vegan pizza that I received and you, too, will be all gaga over it. 

I truly appreciate the care & attention given to us by our waiter. It's so refreshing when someone actually seems like they care! I mean, it was him who made the suggestions. I tend to demure and take the path of least resistance, but really, it shouldn't be too much trouble to merely leave off cheese and add some vegetables to a pie if someone doesn't eat dairy, should it? They didn't make me feel like it was trouble or annoying at all and on top of that, seemed to be eager to offer up ways to make the pizza into a delicious work of art.

Bravo, Archive! You have a new diehard fan.
author: Joi B.

description: DiMaggio is my favorite, highly recommended! It's a win because it's baseball. Only communists don't like baseball. Everything else looked amazing too.
author: Jose G.

description: Been again a few times, twice on MealPal for the Mission Chicken and Pulled Pork Sandwich and just now for the Pastrami sandwich.  That last one was really outstanding as to the Pastrami quality and also a generous amount. I swapped out sour kraut and Rye for cole slaw and soft roll to my liking.  Good pepper action, roll was excellent as was before on previous visits.  Deserved of the $13.75 price.  Nice chips and pickles came with it; seating available for 3 at prime time so good location if you don't want to wait for a nice mid-week lunch.
author: Marc S.

description: When a bartender who I highly respect told me we were going to get wine Manhattan's after work and swore that it would be one of the best Manhattan's I would ever have, well let's just say I wasn't at all convinced! Now I like wine as much as the next guy however I love whiskey! So here's how this went; he ordered two of these "wine Manhattan's", The bartender starts by lighting this little piece of wood on fire and putting the glass upside down over it to smoke the glass. Then using from what I understand to be wines and fermented liquors served me a nice looking cocktail! And then I tasted it!!!  WOW!!! After 3 I felt just as good as I would feel drinking 3 Manhattan's! Although I don't get to come here nearly often enough due to them closing at 10 PM this is now one of my favorite bars! I definitely recommend it for an afternoon date or if you're just walking around in FiDi and want to enjoy a nice lunch paired with a great beverage stop by this place!!! It's small however has a nice rustic decor and chill atmosphere! Plus the owner is a real cool dude! Had a great conversation with him when I stopped in last with a friend and found out that he actually built all the awesome shelves in the bar himself with reclaimed wood!!! Overall great spot, great vibes!!! I love telling people the story of the best Manhattan I've ever had and how it wasn't even made with whiskey! So to anyone who is reading this, check this place out! It's a gem!!!
author: Aleisha T.

description: Good food, wine and friendly staff. Have come here many times after work and on a weekend and am always pleased.
author: Penny B.

description:
I was craving something hearty and the spicy 1906 pizza caught my eyes. The pizza had three kinds of meats: copa, salami, and pepperooni. Also tried the truffle orzo mac and cheese which was tasted good; you can't really go wrong with that cheesy goodness. 

The place itself is a nice small space but it definitely gets packed at dinner time so be prepared to wait and/or be open to sitting on the outside patio.
author: Drew R.

description:
Three skinny friends walk into a bar...

So I'm not someone that's into eating a heavy lunch 'cause I will hit that snooze button in my brain post serious dejeuner nosh fest, and check out for the rest of the day. So for a day of serious seminars, I went to lunch with my two buds to Archive since they had a gluten-free pizza crust our friend could enjoy. 

While service started off a wee bit slow (they were super packed) it was on-point the rest of our lunch. We ordered the Hearst* that is ($16 + $2 for a gluten-free crust) and the Caesar ($10.50). The Caesar isn't Olive Garden big, but we enjoyed sharing it, with our pizza coming out not long after the salad. I really, really enjoyed this pizza. The bacon was chunky bits with perfectly cooked mushrooms, and the slight nutty, rich flavors of the truffle oil. None of the ingredients over-powered the others like you might think they would and the crust was delicious. 

I say three skinny friends walk into a bar, because this seemed to be the perfect amount of food for us three, but I can imagine someone with a bigger appetite or who'd like to have a few beverages with their lunch might find the pricing to be a little on the expensive side whereas we were able to enjoy a delicious lunch for $16 each. 

I'd definitely try them again as a lunch option when I come back to San Francisco!

Caesar* - Little Gem Lettuce, Parmesan Vinaigrette, Bread Crumbs & Spanish White Anchovy
Hearst* - White Truffle Oil, Goat Cheese, Fresh Mozzarella, Wildi Mushrooms & Bacon
author: Morgan F.

description:
My friends said SF is not much of a pizza place. Archive does not help refute that statement. The crust was just too thick and doughey. 

The place was relatively empty on a Monday night. The tomato and burrata salad was meh. The Hearst pizza was good, though personally I thought the goat cheese detracted from it. The Lucas pizza was disappointing. You get one sad piece of too thick prosciutto per slice, and the baked apple slices are mealy.

There is a happy hour, I think from 3-6.
author: Eva W.

description:
I want to give 5 stars because Archive has some really great food. It's also so cutely decorated and the staff is really friendly. I've been here a few times and tried a variety of things on the menu, but my favorites are: 

- Hearst Pizza: definitely the #1 pizza they have. I was honestly shocked at how good this was.
- Garcia Pizza: not sure what happened to this because I've never seen it on the menu after that time I tried it, but it was bomb. They use asparagus, garlic oil, arugula and egg on the pizza... do i need to say any more? 
- Pork Belly Sliders: SO GOOD. The apples and jam really put it over the top. 

Okay so if I like the food so much, why am I giving it only 4 stars? To be frank, the drinks suck. lol. I've had their sangrias and tried a few cocktails but each one I've tried, I leave feeling like I just wasted money drinking something I didn't like at all. 

TLDR: hearst pizza, porkbelly sliders, don't order their cocktails/sangria - stick to the wines and beers imo.
author: Estelle C.

description: Great ambiance and good date spot.  Their gluten free pizza is pretty good but it's honestly just about the only thing on the menu you can eat if you are allergic.  The drinks are really good and they have good happy hour specials.
author: Kati R.

description: Ended up in the financial district on a Friday later than expected from happy hour and my friend and I was so hungry so popped over to Archive. Right off the bat, everyone we encountered was just overall really pleasant personality. We asked if they could the fan off that was right above us and they didn't even hesitate which was so nice of them. To order, we split the orzo truffle mac and cheese. Not my favorite as I think the orzo leads to a soupy mac cheese but good taste overall just not my favorite. Next week ordered the beet salad and a pizza to split. Being a Friday during lent, I had to nix the meat but didn't want to limit my friend and the waiter was more than willing to do a half and half pizza. The beet salad was really tasty, and came with grapes, arugula and quinoa and was a nice compliment to the salad. As for the pizza... I don't know what it was but the pizza crust might have been some of the chewiest most delicious crust ever. I couldn't get over it. Overall, ended up with an app, a salad, a pizza and 2 glasses of wine for $75 which SF food goggles can deal with that pricing. Highly recommend this place for great food and awesome service!
author: Aryn C.

description:
I came here on a weekday for lunch.  Disclaimer: It's really crowded and loud so this may not be the best place to have a meeting.  

The pizza was pretty good.  We had the Lucas pizza.  Apple on pizza is actually really good!  The salads are large and can easily be split between two people.  Overall, it was a satisfying meal with good food portions, but nothing stood out so much that would make me come running back for more.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Overpriced & Average but cool Atmosphere!

Came here for lunch just before a visit to the SFMoMA. My friend and I ordered a Mission Chicken Sandwich and a Pizza (forgot the name). The food was very "just okay" for what we paid. Had the crust on the pizza been different I could see liking it, the sandwich.... just so bland. I think the chicken just wasn't seasoned or marinated. Maybe the cook forgot a step? I'm not exactly sure. 

The service was quick, and I will admit the atmoshpere of the bar was pretty cool. Would I go back? Probably not.
author: Chris S.

description:
So we went there for happy hour with a friend, she had a glass of wine and I had a spring sangria.
I have to admit that even though the place looks really nice, I have some bad remarks:
1) Sangria was really bad, tasted just like water only and nothing else ( was supposed to be passion fruit)
2) the waitress after asking us twice if we wanted food, we said no because going for dinner later, she was very rude trying to rush us to leave and never brought us water when we asked for it, not cool!
author: Irina P.

description:
I've been on a pizza kick lately. Archive seemed like the perfect place to continue the gluttony.

Food:
*Prosciutto & burrata: with cornichons, apples & truffle honey ($14)
*Bacon & feta meatballs: served in tomato sauce with fresh herbs & parmesan ($10.50)
*Caesar: hearts of romaine, parmesan vinaigrette, bread crumb & spanish white anchovy ($10.50)
*Orzo mac & cheese ($9)
*Moscone: seasoned sausage, pepperoni, black olives, shredded mozzarella & organic tomato sauce ($15)
*Hearst: white truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, wild mushrooms, roasted garlic & bacon ($16)

I adored the caesar salad. I love anchovies so having a salad topped with anchovy?! I'm in heaven! My favorite pizza was the hearst. I have a weakness for truffle oil and mushrooms, so this was definitely delicious. The orzo mac and cheese was a little odd. When served, it kind of looked like french onion soup. A little too oily for me.

Drinks:
*Tony bennett "manhattan style": fermented whiskey, barrel aged vermouth, cherry herring & old fashioned bitters ($12)
*Fort point, westfalia amber ale, san francisco, abv 4.6% ($7)
*Mission, doubleipa, san diego ca, abv 9.25% ($8)

I got the manhattan. It was good. Nicely balanced. The rest of our party ordered beers. Can't say anything bad about the combo of beer and pizza.

Out of all my pizza outings lately, Archive has been one of the best. If you're craving pizza, check them out!
author: Elena N.

description:
Great place
Great food
Cool environment
Solid menu
Pizza was really very good!!
We had a great time
author: Eat'n O.

description: Awesome service, deliciously tasty food :), great ambiance, close to my work, good prices! I'll come back!! We had several pizzas including the basic simple but we'll balanced Margherita, 2 amazing salads, both of them super tasty and flavorful. I'm glad we tried this spot for lunch with my colleagues today!!
author: Rachida I.

description:
I have been here for lunch and happy hour and love the drinks, food and atmosphere. 

It can get busy so arrive early or be ready to wait a little. 

Located right on Mission and Montgomery there are lots of work peeps here. This can be fun or annoying if you don't want to see coworkers. 

Order lots of pizza, a cheese plate, brussels sprouts and wine. This will cure a lousy day. 

Tables are close together so avoid bringing older folks here unless you like hearing comments like "whoa, they pack you in like sardines here!"  

Service is friendly and attentive. I have lots of love for servers that see a nearly empty wine glass and offer a refill - the answer is always, yes!
author: Alison C.

description:
Things I look for in a great happy hour spot: close to BART, good beer, delicious food, and happy hour deals (duh)! Archive Bar & Kitchen has all of this along with exceptional service.

HAPPY HOUR DEALS (3-6pm)
- $1 off draught beer
- $2 off house libations
- $5 house wine
- $30 sangria pitchers
- $2 off any pizza
- $4 pork belly sliders

Because they get really busy, they won't seat you unless your whole party is there. Half my party wouldn't be here for another hour, so they let us sit at a two top first. When they came later, they moved us to a four top. Very nice! :)

- Orzo Mac & Cheese ($9): Orzo, Cheddar, Parmesan, Truffle Oil & Breadcrumbs. The dish was creamy and cheesey... that's some delicious gourmet mac n cheese!
- Pork Belly Sliders ($4 during HH, usually $5.50): Braised Pork Belly, Herb Salad & apple served on a Brioche Bun. The pork belly was so juicy! And it was a nice contrast with the apple.
- Hearst Pizza ($15): White Truffle Oil, Goat Cheese, Fresh Mozzarella, Wild Mushrooms & Bacon. This pizza was so flavorful, and they give huge pieces of bacon.
- Lucas Pizza ($16): Prosciutto, Ricotta, Fresh Mozzarella, Gorgonzola, Pink Lady Apple, Garlic Oil, Onion & Arugula. It tasted healthier than the Hearst, but still yummy. 

I've been dreaming about all the delicious food I ate here... so I'll be sure to make plans to come back soon! Cheers!
author: Christine S.

description: I love this place! Amazing pizza and sandwiches. Quality beer and drinks, and the staff is the best! Warm friendly welcome and amazing service Everytime. I like to sit behind the bar in front of the flat screen and watch a game.
author: Karina E.

description: The food and services was good but it wasn't anything special. Very cozy bar & kitchen. I find a lot of the places in the FIDI that are similar with food and has similar prices. It's a nice place to catch up, get a drink and quick bite with friends or coworkers.
author: Sandy B.

description: Discovered this little gem on accident -- literally walked into the wrong door. Absolutely no regrets! Love the place. The cheese plate is out of this world, and the Prairie Farmhouse Ale they had on tap is one of the best beers I've ever had. Superb!
author: Tim P.

description:
I came here to meet a friend after dinner last night, so I did not eat, but she ordered the brussels sprouts and she loved it.  We drank a couple of glasses of red wine at the table.

I really liked the vibe, the place was pretty packed when I got there at 8pm, but by the time we left a couple of hours later it was quite empty. I liked the looks of Archive, long and narrow, with the bar in the back along the right side of the place. The bartenders and waitstaff were super friendly and cool. Although I didn't eat, I took a look at the menu and it looked scrumptious. I must come back to try the cocktails and the pizza everyone talks about.
author: Massimo M.

description:
I finally know what Katy Perry feels like! Only replace 'kissed' with 'eat' and 'girl' with 'salad.' It's pretty sad but I'm so proud of myself because I ate a salad y'all! And it was real, real good. It was of the regular garden variety but it tasted super fresh like it would be a good home for a gnome if it wasn't in my belly. The dressing was light and lemony which was just the way I like it.

The pizza isn't bad (and when I say not bad I actually mean it's pretty awesome) either. And as other Yelpers have mentioned the crust is definitely eating crust! Don't let those carbs go to waste. I was really impressed by how fast the kitchen was turning out dishes and how attentive the staff was even though the tiny restaurant was packed like sardines at lunchtime. The table favorite was the Moscone which was fantastic because...hello sausage and pepperoni.

Save your Cup-o-Noodles for another day. This is the perfect place for a quick and satisfying lunch.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
We got here after the lunch rush so plenty of open tables. (Btw, trying to find parking downtown is a total nightmare!) Service was very friendly and kept our drinks filled. It's a small place, but very cool vibe. 
We ordered club sandwich and shrimp salad sandwich. Both very large sandwiches that came with chips. Very solid sandwiches! My friend got a beer and I tried their Rosemary lemonade which was actually really good! I wouldn't have thought of that combo for a drink! 

We were both super full, but since the kitchen was switching over to dinner we got to taste the brussle sprouts and the pork belly sliders and they are awesome!!! My friend I went with this time doesn't like pizza (I know, it's blasphemy!) so next time I really want to try one! I can't wait to come back for full on dinner and drinks!
author: Amber M.

description: Good spot for after work drinks or lunch! Pizza is delicious and the cocktails are very good.
author: Rachel C.

description:
This is one of my go-to places for for happy hour or to grab dinner with friends/coworkers. Good variety of beers and other drinks, and the pizzas are fantastic. I've tried the Hearst, Moscone, and margherita and all were excellent - the crust is thin, and the toppings are perfectly balanced and tasty. There's also an interesting selection of appetizers and salads as well that are amenable to sharing. 

Service is efficient and the staff are all friendly and attentive. Cozy feel inside, although it can get pretty busy during peak hours.
author: Oliver L.

description: The same says it all: you enter at this small bar-restaurant and you will find paraphernalia from another one related to libraries, or bookstores. I liked the decor a lot and be able to sit outside (my friend and I found a table, what a miracle, this place is always packed!). I used to work last year very close by Archive and was my place to go for a beer. I was in SF to do some errands and an ex-colleague from the UK was visiting my former company, so this was the chosen place to catch up over refreshing beers under the scarce SF sun! Perfect service, location and decor.
author: Carmen V.

description:
There are two types of people in life: Those who eat their pizza crusts, and those who don't... or are at least very choosey about the ones they do allow to slip past their lips.

I happen to be the latter. 

No crust shall pass my person unless something truly magical is going on, but certainly no hard, crusty, burnt end stuff gets past me. For this reason, archive just isn't my thing. It's def a crust-people sort of place. 

The service was outstanding, while even sitting on the patio with a friend and puppy in tow, but I don't know, man... this just isn't my type of pizza.

Speaking from just my personal tastes, I liked the pizza about a 3, but the rosé by the glass and super friendly service evens the average out to a 4. 

Fancy pizza with figs and blue cheese is cool and all, but I'm just not a fancy pants like that. I don't like sweet things on my pizza and if you're not a meat-eater, it's hard to navigate the menu without going sweet. I'm weary of pizza with arugula on it because it's basically a salad pizza and while those two things on their own are great, they have different chew rates and I just don't like trying to carefully eat the arugula so I'm not only swallowing the pizza portion and have all the greens still stuck to my teeth, 

I kind of wish they let you build your own and throw whatever ingredient options they have on there so I didn't have to choose between a white pizza (no thanks, ever) or the figgy pie, but it was fine. 

If you have a more refined pizza palate, Archive is perfect for you... maybe even perfect for a casual date. But if you're like me and like your sauce red, your cheese salty, your toppings savory, and your crust a little soggy, well... I just moved here so I don't know which direction to point you, but thanks for reading this far... sucker! (jk, you're probably a really nice person. I was just raised by wolves.)
author: Candice G.

description:
Most every bar and restaurant in SoMa or the Financial District is packed between 5:30-8 pm. Try getting a glass of wine anywhere within a 3 mile radius around that time on a Friday, I dare you!

Archive is one of those tucked away gems that has space for you at the bar. Sit down, have a glass of wine, order some cheese and have a friendly chat with the bartender. Or watch the vintage streetcar video of SF, taken a few days before the 1906 earthquake. Either way, it's not jam packed with post-work lurkers. I like it.

Pizza is pretty good. Both visits, I had the pie with fig and blue cheese. Sweet and savory with a nice puffy crust. Way better than eating questionable bar nuts or salty popcorn. 

The wine? Ooh yeah! Rose by the glass and carafes are the way to go. Cameron behind the bar will make sure you're not empty for long.

Pop on in for happy hour and you might not leave until well until the evening.
author: Abby S.

description:
5-star lunch. 

A pal and I met here for a weekday (semi-leisurely) lunch and it was as good as it gets. We scored a seat on the small sidewalk patio to soak up some rare SF rays, ordered 2 glasses of sparkling rose, and were quickly furnished with fresh, flavorful salads. I opted for the black bean and added chicken....a healthy portion and delicious. 

Service was on point. We were asked no less than 4x if we wanted more wine. That means that 4x I had to really resist the urge to make it a 2-drink lunch, and it was tough. These girls were sweet AND efficient AND apparently wanted me to get sauced. I wish I could've complied but had to run and catch a plane home. 

Archive this: Fresh salads, fast, not crazy cramped or busy, nice wine. Done and done. 

Total price: $51.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Awesome! Came here on a friday night, the place was busy but not so busy that we couldn't find a table at around 9pm. 

Ordered a Dimaggio 'Pie' and a mac n cheese- to everyone who comes here, ABSOLUTELY try the Orzo mac n cheese. It was amazingggg.

the servers are great and the bus boys even nicer, definitely coming back, perhaps next time for happy hour~ heard great things.
author: Evelyn W.

description: Been here a handful of times and can't say I've been disappointed, whether it be for lunch or dinner, the pizza is where its at.  The Hearst or Coit selections are the go to for me.  Came here with someone and they were gonna get a salad, but decided against it to get a pizza cause the price would have been a couple dollars more with chicken on the salad.  Haha, value.  The service is good and the waiters keep up with you, but how could they not the place is fairly small.  A few spots on the inside and a couple tables on the outside.  The bar is filled with Wine and beer and a few Libations.  I usually get some Reds, like the Pinot Noir here.  All in all a good spot for the business crowd and for lunch.  I will be back as it is only down the street from work.
author: Jeremaine R.

description:
Went here for dinner and drinks the other night and was pleasantly surprised. I walk by this place a lot on my way to work but have never actually gotten around to trying it. This place is pretty small but super trendy and great vibes. 

DRINKS:
- Mission Brewing Shipwrecked Double IPA - great choice
- Witness Tree Estate Pinot Blanc - delish (similar to Pinot Grigio)

FOOD: (split both items)
-Truffle Orzo Mac and Cheese - amazing but super heavy and creamy, also got a little mushy because it was orzo but overall really great to share!
- Moscone Pizza - really yummy pizza with sausage, pepperoni, black olives, mozzarella and tomato sauce 

These two items were more than enough to split. We couldn't even finish the whole pizza! The food was great though, I will definitely be back soon.
author: Ilana B.

description:
I came here with tres amgios for the lunch of a lifetime! It was an epic SF afternoon and we were perusing for some trouble. We decided to kick down the doors of Archive and get what we wanted...delicious artisan pizza (& a salad, duh). We didn't even have a wait! 

We split a pizza and salad because we were looking for a light lunch. The salad we got was Caesar and boy was it perfect. It was the perfect precursor to a radical ZA. We opted for the "Hearst" pizza. It has bacon, truffle oil, mushrooms, goat+mozzarella cheese and a perfectly made gluten free crust (gluten free for a small extra charge). It was sooooooo good. Literally the perfect ingredients. I need to recreate this masterpiece...

If I were hungry, I'd probably be able to manhandle my own pizza but I wasn't in the mood. Just needed something to keep the waistline slim and the stummy full. I'd totes go back.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Great spot for lunch or dinner!

The Lucas & DiMaggio pizzas are my favorite - give them a try.
author: Ananya M.

description:
Been wanting to check out Archive for so long and finally had the perfect excuse!  A dinner catch up on Thursday night.  We got there a little after 5:30 and it was already starting to get crowded.  The only tables that could fit us had the reserved sign, but they saw me walk in and look around and asked me if I would be ordering food or just drinks, I told them food too, so they let us sit there.  Guess that's their way of saving it for people that want to dine, pretty smart.

Only thing on their happy hour menu for food was a dollar off the pork belly sliders.  My sangria which I just got a glass of was a few bucks off.  The guys got wine and beer that wasn't a part of happy hour.  We decided to start with the orzo mac n cheese, the fried brussel sprouts, and the Hearst Pizza. The Sangria was rose based and was nice and refreshing.  I wish I had a little more hints of fruit in there though.  The orzo mac n cheese was very different as orzo is a rice shaped pasta, and it was served more like a dip as crostinis were served along side.  It had a hint of truffle and was a nice alternative to traditional Mac n cheese.  Reminded me of a savory rice pudding.  There was a hint of truffle oil.  The two waiters were slammed, and we asked for extra crostini pieces, but never got them.  No biggie, we were resourceful and used our crust to dip it in, and ate it by itself too.  If you love mac n cheese and love rice, then I would suggest you get this.  The brussel sprouts weren't chips per say, but when I got the leaf pieces, it reminded me of Marlowe's chips, but way better then theirs. They were well seasoned and not overly greasy.  We substituted the goat cheese for ricotta on the Hearst.  The Hearst was our favorite.  It had truffle oil, mozzarella, wild mushrooms, pancetta (and originally goat cheese too).  It was a perfect marriage of flavors with the two cheeses, and the woodsiness of the mushrooms and slight saltiness oft he pancetta.  And we love our truffle oil!  I would have just like the crust cooked a little more to get some crisp to it.  

We were still a little hungry, so we got the Lucas pizza too, which I was honestly eyeing too!  It was topped with apple slices, gorgonzola, proscuitto, arugula, garlic oil, mozzarella, and ricotta.  The pizza was quite rich with the assortment of cheeses and that stanky gorgonzola.  The salty, savory and sweet elements were enjoyable.  I used to love gorgonzola, but now I find it a little too strong for me, I think if it weren't for the gorgonzola I would have loved the pie, although we all enjoyed it, the Hearst was the winner.  Again, I thought the crust could be crispier.
