I'm so glad I finally got to check out Archive.  It's a great place to grab a drink and some dinner or munchies with a couple of friends.  I would really like to see what lunch is like here too.  4 stars.
author: Cat C.

description:
WOW, who shoved a stick up your bum miss little cocktail waitress who looks like a heavier version of Hayden Panettiere???

I was meeting 2 girlfriends for cocktails on a MONDAY night. They got their first and took a table for 4 - they said the waitress gave them attitude for sitting at a 4 top, and asked "where is your friend" implying they might have to move to a 2 top when I was 5 minutes late. (SIDE note: the place never filled up in the 2 hours we were there, so not sure why she was so concerned)

Anyway I order a $12 cocktail and ask for a "big glass of very icy water" she brings my cocktail and a glass of water - no ice, I ask again and she says " the water is as cold as ice" -- okay - but can I still have a BIG glass of ice? - she huffs off and brings me a short glass of ice..okay, I'm still happy to see my friends and not too upset. Then more attitude from her. The place is 3/4's empty and we have to flag her down to order food - we order a pizza and brussels sprouts.  When we were halfway through the pizza we asked about the spouts... "oh I though you were just asking about them, not ordering them" Seriously what the F?   

Then she tries to take away our dishes when we are clearly still eating. 

A group of businessmen come in after we had been there for about 45 minutes, she was at that table for about 10 minutes and kept their drinks filled, so not quite sure what we did to her, but we will not be back.
author: Amy W.

description:
More watering hole than eatery judging by the extensive display of libations they offer (photo: http://bit.ly/18L8sp9), this is still an unexpected find at a pretty busy location on Mission right off Second Street in the lower FiDi. This space was where Mondo Caffe operated for a number of years in what looked to be a thriving lunchtime business. I used to have the occasional porchetta panini there, and it was good eatin' albeit pretty greasy for a coldly impersonal colleague lunch. Except for the three thin-crust pizzas on their menu, the Italianate influence has disappeared in favor of new American bar bites. There is now an Old San Francisco feel to the exposed brick and Edison bulbs, but the ambiance is casually contemporary (photo: http://bit.ly/IOYhsZ).

I happened upon Archive on the third day of their operation last week, and the place was only half-full. There were empty seats at the bar, so I parked myself while perusing their brief lunch menu (photo: http://bit.ly/1cw7bDi). I landed upon their $8 Bits & Gems Salad, a most refreshing plate of little gem lettuce with radish slices and freckled with bits of Applewood smoked bacon and pomegranate seeds. It was drizzled with an Asiago cream dressing that lent a bit of tartness to the plate (photo: http://bit.ly/18QaPtO). I enjoyed the salad, and it made me want to come back with a friend to try one of their pizzas and a house drink like the Atlas Apple which features strong cider, chai, walnut bitters and spiced pear foam. Sounds perfect for this time of the year.

FOOD - 4 stars...refreshing salad, simple and tasty
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...turn-of-the-last-century vibe with a contemporary twist
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly and jovial
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice addition to the local bar scene, looking forward to their full food menu
author: Ed U.

description: We ordered the fall special pizza and it was tasty! I was hesitant about having squash and pomegranate seeds in my pizza, but the flavor came together really well and it was on the lighter side. One order can easily be split for 2 and we were even able to add in a side of Mac n cheese (which I highly recommend). They don't have a full liqueur license so drinks are a little limited. We ordered the sangria rose and it was pretty light and was on the sweeter side. Don't let it fool you though, I definitely felt that drink later
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Came here on their soft opening week and it was delish!
They didn't have their full menu but all the pizzas and the salad we tried were all good. Prices are reasonable for the area.
Service was attentive for our group of 10. I would definitely come back for lunch and happy hour.
author: Angela D.

description:
Another Happy Hour place within close proximity to my office by Montgomery BART. I came with a few friends the Friday before Labor Day and it wasn't too crowded around 5:30 PM. 

From memory, I think their Happy Hour is weekdays 3-6 PM and the specials included $6 Spring Sangria, $4 beers, and $4 house red/white wines. Unfortunately they didn't have a printed Happy Hour menu or sign, despite older pictures on Yelp. And they also didn't have a Happy Hour price on food, which was sad because I enjoyed their Sutro pizza with its whole garlic and fresh ricotta cheese...mmm. I guess I'll just have to get this during regular lunch or dinner!

We only came for a couple of Spring Sangrias and they were strong! Not a bad deal for $6, but they were on the smaller side. I'd come back again for a quick drink but go elsewhere for Happy Hour food specials.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Really liked this place. It was my first stop for something to eat when I arrived in San Fran and after I checked into my hotel. It seems like a bar restaurant that attracts the young, local business folk. I felt like maybe I was the only tourist. Dim mood lighting but still showing sports on the tv, it was a nice balance of trendy artisan pizza spot and place you could go to calmly watch a game. 

I enjoyed a seasonal sangria that had apple and cinnamon spices. It was good, but I would have preferred it to be more spiced. It still tasted somewhat summery. All in all pretty good though.

It was sort of late for lunch so I decided to have a pork belly slider and the cheese plate. The slider was on happy hour special so it was a dollar off. I didn't think it was all that good. The pork wasn't so flavorful and tasted a little like the oil it may have been heated in. I could have done without it. 

The cheese plate was really very good. I believe it came with 3 or 4 cheeses, all cut in thin triangular slices, with a generous 3 or 4 slices each. It came with round toasted bread slices and square crackers as well as honey, a fig jam and some toasted spiced nuts. I don't know what kind of cheeses there were - the waitress thought they were some kind of goat, but I would have expected them to be creamier if that was the case. It would have been nice if the staff knew the cheeses they included, but luckily I like almost all cheeses so I wasn't worried. There was only one I didn't eat because it was just kind of dull in comparison to the others. The fig jam was sweet and thick and sticky and complimented all these cheeses, as did the honey. The nuts were a nice additional snack. The plate was really filling. 

For what it's worth, their pizzas looked pretty delicious. I just didn't want to spoil my dinner, otherwise I would have considered. 

I liked the atmosphere, the crowd, the cheese plate and the pizza (in theory). A great spot to check out!
author: Samantha M.

description: If you're coming here for food, you'll be absolutely disappointed. The bar is nice and cozy though but the worst pizza I had in my life. Also it's way overpriced for this quality
author: Rana K.

description:
Archive Bar & Kitchen is a good addition to the neighborhood.

In a narrow storefront with dark cut concrete floors and exposed brick walls, Archive Bar & Kitchen is a good place for lunch or happy hour. Looking like it has been in place forever, there are vintage tchotchkes among the bottles behind the bar and period fans on the ceiling.

With the limited kitchen space, the menu at Archive Bar & Kitchen is surprisingly well-rounded. Lunch consists of an array of sandwiches from the the healthy Archive Club ($14) featuring thin slices of turkey, bacon, avocado, arugula, green tomato, and roasted garlic aioli to the hearty pastrami and peppers ($13) with thin slices of pastrami, sweet and spicy peppers, sauerkraut, Irish cheddar, and Ruasian dressing. All the sandwiches are sizable and delicious.

The real star of the show is the pizza. With sausage, pepperoni, black olives, mozzarella, and organic tomato sauce, the Moscone ($16) was tasty. The thin-to-medium crust is cooked perfectly to a nice light brown. Light and airy it is more chewy than crispy, but still nicely done. Very flavorful, the Hearst ($15) sports white truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, wild mushrooms huge hunks of bacon.

Dinner adds various "Bites and Boards," ranging from the amazingly creamy truffle orzo Mac and cheese ($8) to bacon and feta meatballs ($10.50) served with fresh basil and a hearty tomato sauce. 

A few local craft beers are on tap. The well-priced but short wine list features west coast wines with a few offerings from Argentina. Although Archive Bar & Kitchen lacks a full liquor license, it does offer some "cocktails" beaded on sake or Ron Copa Rica wine-based "rum."

A warning: it gets crowded at lunch and happy hour, so be prepared.

For lunch or happy hour, you can't go wrong at Archive Bar & Kitchen.
author: CJ G.

description:
I called to make a lunch reservation and they told me they don't take any. Fine. I get there a little early just in case. What do I see?? Two tables with "Reserved" signs on them.

I ordered he Hearst pizza w/o garlic sauce. Tasty.

Good service. 

So...Poor ventilation, extremely loud setting, and being lied to on the phone. I don't think  I'll be back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Whoa.

Get yourself here, guys.

Stop holding your team lunches at your regular spots because Archive is really, really good. They seriously offer the best pizzas and salads I've had in the area, paired with some really great things on tap.

The 'Lucas' pizza ($17) was a good combination of light and heavy flavors with prosciutto, ricotta, fresh mozzarella, gorgonzola, apple slices, garlic oil, onion & arugula. Although, the 'Hearst' (also $17) with white truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, wild mushrooms & bacon really stole the show for me. The bacon comes in THICK, freshly cut cubes. Oh my gawd, this pizza is so good. 

FYI, the full-size salads are huuuuge and can easily be shared amongst your table.

The space is intimate and cozy with exposed brick, and century-old footage showing on their TV's of people riding their Model T's down Market Street to the Ferry Building.

I'm all about this place.
author: K M.

description:
Solid spot for lunch during the work week. It's close to the office, very tasty, and usually has a good turn around time. It's always busy, but somehow we've never had to wait for table. We can get in and out in under 40 minutes, so I keep coming back.

Have only had their pizza, all of which were great. The Lucas, DiMaggio, and Hearst are the ones that stay on the regular rotation. Service is good, prompt and friendly and they usually don't interrupt during the meal to ask how everything is, which is nice during the lunch rush hour. If the weather is nice, they have a handful of tables outside. The only downside is the inside can get loud. It can be difficult to hear the person across from you if you don't lean in or raise your voice. If there are more than four in the party you probably won't be hearing what everyone says.
author: Michael S.

description:
Archive is fantastic. It has a snazzy ambience and a good selection of artisan pizzas. My favorite is the Lucas: prosciutto, ricotta, mozzarella, gorgonzola, apple slices, garlic oil, onion, and arugula. It might sound a little crazy, especially with the apple, but the flavors work well together and it's delicious. I've also had the Moscone and Hearst, which were both good but not as good as the Lucas, at least in my opinion. The salads also look good, but I've never had them; the pizza is too good!

They have a good selection of beers on tap too and a pretty extensive cocktail menu for a dinner place. My favorite used to be the Behind the Green Door, which was a green lychee drink served in a goblet but they didn't have it the last time I went. So it goes. Archive is still worth coming to for the pizza and beer, and I'll definitely be back.
author: Nikhil S.

description:
Four stars for the food, three stars for the price. I had a om-nommy sando plus a small side salad. Not going to lie--that alcoholic root beer was looking mighty fine, even though it was noon on a weekday.

At first glance, the side salad looked like a bad move. $3? For the clump of lettuce? But then, friends, I dug in. That side salad had a panoply of things: cheese, tomatoes, almonds, cucumber. It was a delight. And a way better move than the $14 sandwich. She sandwich was good, but damn, was it pricey. $20 lunches aren't generally my thing.

The people watching was also great--right on Mission Street. Be warned, you'll have to hear the traffic and other such nonsense, but such is SoMa. 

The good: good food.
The bad: they want all your dollars.
Pro tip: get there about five minutes to noon and you won't have any problem finding a seat. If you arrive after noon, good luck.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I loved the food!!!
The Hearts pizza was amazing!!!
Drinks are really good too
My favorite is the Tony Bennet
author: Monica D.

description:
I'm so happy that this trendy establishment popped up right near where I work! This hidden gem makes for a great lunchtime spot to grab pizza with friends or to enjoy an evening libation after a long day working in the FiDi. 

The pizzas they have are packed with delicious ingredients: I'm talking goat cheese, cloves of garlic, and lots of different veggies. This ain't no dominos here. The seating is very tight, so while I was annoyed at people scooting past me, I also got a good view of pretty much everything else on the menu, ordered by patrons at the neighboring tables 1.5 feet away from me. Everything else looked good, and the staff was friendly and somewhat quick.

Once you get past the tight spaces and armies of yuppies you need to shove past to get a seat, you'll really enjoy this neat little spot!
author: Stephen D.

description:
They are super crowded but the staff is really nice and surprisingly accommodating. They pretty much have a full bar and serve some pretty drinks (like the Watermelon fog which should be called the Gandalf). 

Their main draw is supposed to be their pizza and I think the 'artisanal' ingredients (ie: truffle oil, fat pieces of bacon) are good but the dough is really lacking. I still prefer places like Tony's and even Zero Zero but this is a fun place to hang out.
author: Karen S.

description:
Misleading prices on the happy hour. Beer is not included in the Happy Hour menu. Another table complained about the same problem left with $45 bill for 2 drinks and a dish. Our party of 3 left with $75 bill.

FYI: Apparently, $2 off on Libitations means a few dollars of 10 custom cocktails.  The cocktails are weak in alcohol volume. Hmm, try food instead?
author: Peter G.

description:
EDIT:  Wow, rude response from the owner.  

There is nothing false about my review.  My friends and I were all mislead into thinking that the cocktails contained actual liquor.  Also, as I said, I would have been happy to enjoy another type of drink had I known what it was I was buying.  If you want to know about the quality of the cocktail it was (like the food) completely forgettable.  

Here's a hint, Gabriel-- businesses are about your customers, and reviews are about constructive criticism.  Sorry you got your feelings hurt.

**************

This place gets packed during happy hour, but my friends and I were able to grab a table.  The food was so mediocre I can't even remember exactly what we ordered (some kind of pizza and some appetizers).  

However, the worst thing by far about this place is their misleading House Libations cocktail menu, which lists several types of drinks specialty drinks, including drinks containing "fermented vodka", "fermented whiskey", "fermented rum", etc.  The average consumer (myself included) would assume that this list contains cocktails with actual distilled spirits (especially considering the prices of these "cocktails", which are on par with those containing liquor), however, apparently "fermented" is another way of saying "not liquor."

I get that not every place has a liquor license, and I'm totally fine with beer and wine only, but why masquerade as something you're not?  My friends and I were very disappointed to get our drinks with no liquor in them.  Misleading advertising, in my opinion, and at the very least, it makes for an unhappy customer who was hoping for real whiskey in their glass.  We won't be returning.
author: Erin B.

description: Went here for some drinks and apps after work. The cocktails were way too sweet and on the weaker side. They apparently also don't have a full bar, so they weren't able to make other drinks off the cocktail menu. The sliders trio were pretty good, but the orzo mac & cheese wasn't very flavorful and felt too runny. However, this place had efficient and friendly service.
author: Critic X.

description:
Found this place thanks to Yelp on my most recent visit to San Francisco.  Went on a Monday night and it was pretty empty.   Our server was super nice/friendly and gave my husband good beer recommendations.  

We ordered:
- popcorn prawns:  pretty big portion....was perfectly crispy and juicy.  I liked the Thai chili sauce it came with
- Margarita Pizza:  Yummy...can't go wrong with tomatoes, basil and mozzarella
- Caesar Salad: BY FAR, the best caesar salad I've ever had.  The dressing was creamy and the bread crumbs on top perfectly complemented the dish.  YUMMY.  Would highly recommend.

Dinner was sweet and simple.  Just the way I wanted it.
author: Rina L.

description:
Delicious pizza and great service! The waiters went the extra mile by checking in often, providing excellent recommendations, and even going to the back to bring out balsamic vinegar and olive oil for me :)

Inside is really nice as well, with a warm and welcoming ambience.
author: Anna X.

description:
Stopped by around 9 on a Thursday to a pretty quiet joint. Bartender (and owner?) was manning everything out front, given that there were maybe at most 3 small groups/individuals including us at the time total the whole time we were there. He was very friendly; also mentioned that they ran out of the pulled pork, since he stopped serving it as it was not up to par anymore by that time. I like that he cares about the quality of his food.

Pizza is a decent thin crust, but the crust is nothing to rave about. I prefer the edges to be the crusty chewy bulbous kind as seen on a good neopolitan pizza fired in a high-temp oven. They don't serve that style here. The toppings on the squash pizza and the meat one were both tasty though. Wish they were a little more liberal with some of the ingredients. By comparison for example, Casey's Pizza is more generous and more to my liking in general. I'd give this pizza a 3, and something like Delfina a 5 in the thin crust department.

I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt since they're so new that the food will be even better as they get into a good groove. Looks like it'd be a great place for drinks after work, too. Nice vibe here, just needs some more people inside.
author: Linus W.

description:
THE BEST MUSHROOM PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD.  5/5! 

My co-workers and I came here for lunch on a Monday afternoon and the place was packed. However, the owner was really nice and set up tables for us outside. The menu isn't that big but it serves all meat lovers, vegetarians, pescetarians, etc. 

(+) HEARST PIZZA. My favorite pizza on the menu! It's even better if you ask for extra arugula on top. Hands down the best mushroom pizza have ever tried. I'm not a big fan of goat cheese but it went really well with the mushrooms. The pizza crust is really thin and the mushroom makes the center really soggy but the overall pizza is so good that I didn't mind. The pizza isn't that big, perfect for one if you're hungry. If you don't finish it, no worries because it still tastes delicious when it's cold later on! 

I also really like the diMaggio and the Margarita ! Not a big fan of the Lucas, but that's just me. 

The service was really good. The waiters were constantly refilling our water. The food did take awhile but it's a nice atmosphere for sit down and chat with your friends. I do recommend getting there right when it opens to get a good seat. Can't wait to come back to this place !

HAPPY HOUR: I love the pork belly sliders! Kind of pricey as it's $4 per slider but it's pretty worth trying it. 

DRINKS: The GIMLET is AMAZING. Don't pass up on it
author: Tram N.

description: This place is amazing!!! True it's small- but what awesome bar isn't in SF? Does anyone ever say, this place is awesome and huge? Never. It just doesn't happen. It's almost like the smaller the place the better. It's like supply and demand- oh there's a ton of people waiting outside- this place must be bomb. Well this place is not exception. Definitely bomb and the pizza is amazing! I mean for 16 bucks for a pizza I probably could have eaten on my own better have been worth it. The sangria was delicious and I'm very picky with it. They have wine and beer, but no full bar. Womp womp. The pizza we ordered had basil and ricotta and pears. So delicious!! I deducted a star only because they didn't have a full bar and it was fairly pricey for the amount of food you got. But it's SF after all! Still I would come here again - if I'm in the mood to wait that is.
author: Heather S.

description: My boyfriend and I chose to grab lunch here as soon as we arrived in the city during our last visit to SF. The gluten free pizza is amazing!!! The staff is extremely friendly here as well as attentive. We came in just before the lunch rush but noticed that many people came in on their lunch breaks solo - the service was prompt and food served in a timely fashion. Everything we ordered was delicious. The decor/music/atmosphere is fun, relaxed and covers street noise without making it difficult to hold a conversation while dining. We will definitely be back again!
author: Madison S.

description:
This place bums me out. Inconsistent service and bartenders who act like they are doing ME a favor (Hence chick in nerd glasses with ruby red lips). Having been a bartender in college, it really fires me up when I am treated like crap...but when it is time to pay, bartenders/servers are nicey-nice. That is what I got...be thankful for the 20% tip you did NOT deserve sweetheart.

I had a jackhat on my left literally sitting his fat behind in my space and the pretentious British Pr@#ck on my right who acted like I had cooties.
You British are real Wankers.
Happy Hour sucks and I hate spending my money at a place where I am made to feel like an inconvenience.
*Blows*
author: LisaLisa F.

description:
i LOVEEEeeeeEe archive. and their $5 house wine during happy hour. and their pizzas. and shishito peppers. 

honestly dont remember what the girls and i did for happy hour drinks before archive existed, but we've been coming foreverrRrr and it's gotten better and better. at first the pizzas were kinda soggy and not delish, but now EVERY SINGLE selection is just fantastic :) MAD PROPS. and the servers, host, AND owner are soo friendly, and definitely hook you up if you're there often enough...

THE BEST.
author: Christina L.

description:
Great for lunch and dinner. Archive's pizza is pretty outstanding and maybe the best gluten free crust around! Try it... even if you don't need to eat gluten free... it's that good!

I would skip the cocktails but they have a nice wine list.

Some of the mouth watering pizzas to choose from: 

DiMaggio :Mild Italian Sausage, Paquillo Pepper, Wild Mushrooms, Ricotta Cheese, Mozzarella & Garden Pesto - Substituting the Pesto for red sauce is also a good idea. 

Sullivan: Roasted Butternut Squash, Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pine Nuts, Arugula & Organic Tomato Sauce

The menu gets updated pretty often - and have also had an amazing bbq pork belly pizza and one that had potatoes and lemon - can't remember what either of them were called - but everytime I go to Archive I search the menu in hopes that they have returned. 

Service is always top notch and typically pretty easy to grab a table for a small party.
author: Shannon H.

description: Came here for dinner with my two other friends. Our water was constantly refilled which was good service, but the pizza was okay. I liked the crispy thin crust but the bottom was a bit burnt on one of our pizzas. We had the Moscone and the Hearst. We replaced goat cheese with regular Parmesan cheese. We also ordered the truffle Mac and cheese, which you can never go wrong with truffle on anything! It was good but didn't have the Mac texture which was weird - it was more like rice with truffle and cheese. Overall good experience with the company I came with. Pizzas could be less burnt at the bottom, but flavor was good! Very loud atmosphere as well, hard for us to hear one another.
author: Amanda C.

description: Loved this place!  Great food and atmosphere. Highly recommend!  Great food - we got roasted brussel sprouts, spinach and artichoke dip, bruschetta....  All very tasty....will definitely go back.
author: Cathy H.

description: Great cocktails, pizza, and atmosphere. Super friendly staff and a fun place for happy hour! Killer cheese plate too..
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I was a huge fan of Mondo Caffe, which occupied this space before Archive opened about a year ago, and I was concerned that my go-to spot for a sit-down lunch might no longer be available. I'm glad to say that Archive does a nice job of providing a slightly nicer-than-usual lunch spot with a chance to sit down and actually talk to your lunch date. Unlike Mondo, Archive has table service, so no need to order at the counter. They do offer takeout, though, which you can order in the back.

The food is good, too. I've had their pizzas, which are tasty and filling, I've had the pastrami sandwich, which comes with chips and is really delicious, and yesterday I had the kale, blue cheese, and nectarine salad, which was a little on the skimpy side, but tasted great. Lunch usually comes out just under $15, which is a little more than I usually spend, but sometimes it's worth paying extra to focus on the conversation.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This is my go-to spot for happy hour after work!

Excellent service, everyone is attentive and friendly, could not ask for a better experience while I wind down after a long day of work.
author: Mario P.

description:
Archive is usually very full since it's not that big of a place inside.  However, when my group of ten people wanted to have some post drinking carbs in the form of pizza, I immediately suggested Archive since it was already 8:30pm and there should be no way that Archive should still be busy.

As predicted, the tables were free so we squeezed into tables, ordered some more booze, and ordered six pizzas from their pizza list.  I was in front of the vegetarian pizzas and despite the lack of meat, these thin slice pizzas were delicious!  One pizza can feed two people moderately.

I'm definitely hooked on the pizza and most likely will be back from all the local bars that don't offer any food.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Me and my girlfriend went here to have a few beers and some sangria, and to meet up with a friend of hers. 

We got in and got a table right away. Ice cold glasses of ice cold beer, sangria was amazing and the service was pretty good. We ordered the sliders (which were heavenly) and we ordered two different pizzas (also crazy good). 

We paid up by splitting the tab, but since me and my gf ordered a beer before her friend arrived, we said we'd pay more of the tip.

Long story short, we ended up leaving a $15 tip on a $150 tab. We're from Norway - where you don't tip at all - and thought that was plenty. In retrospect, we should've bumped it up a few bucks, but oh well - we were all kind of tipsy and I didn't feel like math.

So we leave, but as we are leaving, the waiter comes RUNNING out to us and basically heckles us to give him a bigger tip. "Are you not FROM here?" is a quote I'll remember for a while. 

That ruined the entire night for me. So a 5 star place ended up as a 1 star night - all because of 10 dollars and a douchebag waiter. Will not return. Unfortunately.
author: Kris S.

description:
The food is good, but it's a tad crowded and be prepared for a very noisy and busy atmosphere.

For an appetizer, I split the Popcorn Prawns with two other people. They were delicious, and too my surprise, the "Crispy Lemon" in the description actually meant deep fried pieces of lemon. The lemon tended to fall apart as you tried to eat it, but the flavour was unique and I'd recommend that appetizer to anyone. For my entree, I had the DiMaggio pizza. Taste wise I would call it pretty average, size wise it was perfect for a big guy like me, but will likely be too much for a lot of people.
author: Graham B.

description:
Came by to check out this place since its just around the corner from my office. Loved the prosciutto and buratta appetizer (it came with apple slices and almonds) and the truffle Mac and cheese with orzo was delicious. 

They also have great pizzas, but they can take a while to bake. Lots of beers on tap and the sangria was also great. Would definitely come back for lunch or dinner!
author: Jing L.

description:
I pass by this place often and everyone always look so cheerful and satisfied so I decided to stop in. 

I enjoyed the outdoor dining on Mission and 2nd. I had the pleasure of being served by Dennis S. From the moment he handed me a menu to the moment I left him a well-deserved tip, I was satisfied. 

I truly appreciate him asking me how I was doing. I expressed I has an awful headache. 

As I've never been here before, his menu recommendations were so aligned with my appetite. I enjoyed the Greek olives as well as green olives. I then indulged in two pizzas. Yes, two. We chucked together about my huge appetite, well our huge appetites and how our friends laugh at us about it. 

I enjoyed a nice glass of white wine. I cannot recall the exact wine, but it was delicious and went well with my pizza selections. 

When I was preparing to leave and catch my BART, Dennis checked in and asked about my headache (he remembered). I forgot about it as it completely went away!

For stellar genuine service, great ambiance, delectable food, and comfy yet exquisite dining, find yourself at Archive. I must go back again. Thanks y'all! My night has been made!
author: Renée H.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood, Archive!

And a neighborhood spot it is. Whether I stop by with colleagues for an alfresco lunch or drop in for after-work cocktails, that warm and fuzzy casual feel is always in the air. The manager/owner is usually around and seems super invested in his patrons' experience - what a nice guy!

I've tried their cheese plate and also the pizza. My choice of pie arrived piping hot and topped with bacon, mushrooms, goat cheese, and garlic. I opted for the gluten-free crust and it was phenomenal... I had to stop myself from eating the last three pieces as it was that delicious, yet I was full! Of course, it made for great leftovers.

Not that many people know about Archive yet, and even fewer know about their wonderful cocktails and specialty sodas and lemonades. Throw in a well-curated wine list and some decent craft brews and this is a bar I'll never say 'no' to. Only drawback I can think of? When the pizza ovens are going, this small restaurant gets hot - so hot, that you'll even feel the heat on their outdoor patio. Not a big deal now, but something to think about on one of those rare 80+ degree days!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
Met up with a buddy of mine here tonight around 630, and was surprised that we were able to get seated as easily as we did, considering the place was packed. After a bit of deliberation, we ended up ordering the Hearst (for the truffle oil) and the Garcia (for that soft egg, mm).

Unfortunately, both of us were a little disappointed with our orders. While prepared and baked well, both our pizzas were a bit lacking in flavor and depth: the Hearst, despite having ingredients that have great flavor on their own, fell short, being overwhelmed by the saltiness of the prosciutto; the Garcia, on the other hand, was much tastier, but was almost completely lacking in truffle flavor. We ended up supplementing our slices heavily with chili flakes to boost the flavor.

To be fair, their pizza is not terrible, and is better than that of Zero Zero - all things considered, in another city, I'd probably give Archive a solid three stars. But, given the selection of high quality pizza in the city (Little Star, for example), I can't really see myself coming back here.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A smallish venue consisting mostly of high-top counter seating, or high-top tables. There are a handful of small two to three seater tables outside, as well as a lower counter for two inside, but that's about it.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I ordered a salad. After eating it for about five minutes, I found a large insect in the leaves. I told my waiter, and then the manager came over and told me he would take it off our bill. He did not apologize. After telling him I was disgusted by my meal, he became rude and arrogant in my face. Still no apology. I asked if he could also take care of my two other guests' salads, because we all had the same lettuce leaves, and he said 'Oh so now you're telling me what to do? Now I do what you say?' I was in disbelief.

 He was a jerk and he did not treat me with respect. Finding an insect in your food should definitely warrant an apology. They've lost me, as well as all of my coworkers, as customers.
author: Natalie Q.

description:
Great place for lunch during the work week! This place gets super packed quick so make sure you make a reservation or arrive before the lunch rush.

I highly recommend the Hearst pizza and the chicory salad! I met up with a friend and we split these two items and we were sooo FULL! The Hearst pizza had truffle oil on it and we also added an egg on it. The pizza was thin crust which made it better since I'm not huge fan of pizza crust. The chicory salad was really refreshing and tasty I think we added chicken to this which made this more filling. 

I would love to come back for their happy hour!
author: Christine W.

description:
I really loved Archive Bar & Kitchen. My first visit was for a group lunch and I enjoyed it so much that I went back for a date with my beau that Friday night. On both visits I enjoyed the Mediterranean-style salad with crunchy pita chips. After tasting the chicken alfredo pizza on my first trip, I knew we had to order it again the second time around. A wise choice. The other pizzas I tried were great as well (especially the one with sausage). 

Servers and management were all friendly and helpful. I loved the big bottles of flavored iced tea during my lunch stop and I enjoyed the wine selection even more during my evening visit. Solid spot for lunch, happy hour or dinner. Looking forward to returning next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Checked out Archive during peak lunch hour with a group and we shockingly scored a table to fit our entire group. The seating is pretty sparse and most of the tables are set for four and the set up is true SF fashion in being pretty intimate without being too vast and lofty. 

To best serve our whole group, we split most of the pizzas from the menu. Can't say that I had one that I disliked. Each pie would be more than a formidable meal for one person to take down and they were split amongst our group well. I'm a fan of the crust, too. Nice and chewy with some well-done/crunchy/crispy spots, too. Favorites were the varieties with veggies and goat cheese. The few with meats were equally good. 

Probably the most minute, yet, still notable item on the menu is the rosemary lemonade. It was fantastic. Not too too sweet, packed with flavor, and rather refreshing. Really loved it. 

I'd head back for sure. Great spot for a great meal.
author: Benjamin G.

description: The service was excellent here!  Called ahead to come in with our group of 6 and everyone was super nice and attentive.  Delicious food and drinks!
author: Ashley F.

description: Awesome wine, delicious pizza, my favorite olives, and super friendly staff. Great spot to hang out after work.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Archive is a fabulous addition to the SOMA/FiDi food/drink scene.

My co-workers and I came here for lunch the other day. This new gastropub is literally right around the corner from our office. I'm glad we arrived early, because this place fills up quickly starting at 12pm.

The manager/owner was nice enough to greet us/seat us. He also took the time to tell us about the history of the space (it's one of the few buildings to survive the 1906 earthquake and fire) and walk us through the menu.

As for the food - the kitchen is totally rockin' it. Our party of 5 decided to split a few salads (which are quite large in size) and 3 pizzas. All the pizzas are thin crust and made with seasonal ingredients. Our favorite dish was the chicken pizza, hands down.

Since it was technically a working lunch, we abstained from the booze. But the bar seems like it has a pretty stellar beer and wine selection. And while they don't have a full liquor license, they seem to have some interesting cocktails made with wine and sherry. I'll definitely return soon for happy hour and sampling some of their adult beverages.

All in all, this was a great discovery. Archive seems like it's off to a strong start. And judging by the busy crowd, the word is catching on!
author: Kevin B.

description:
I swung down for Happy Hour just the other day with my girlfriend, and after a beer, I think I kinda dig their groove. They have a pretty sweet happy hour deal -- $2 off pizzas (which are from $13-$15 each), $2 off drafts, $5 house wines, and $6 sangria. They don't have a ton of draft selection, but what they do have is quality. I recommend getting their amber selection. Realllll good. Only complaint with their beers is that it's not quite a pint. I can't imagine paying the normal $7 for a little more than a soda-sized glass beer. Their sangria is a also little lacking - both in size and in flavor. I didn't like it, and the girlfriend definitely didn't like it (she made me drink it). Better stick with their house wine or beer. Their cocktails are reasonably priced and sound great, but I didn't get a chance to try one, so I won't venture out there. 

Overall, it's a nice place to hang out if you want to grab some drinks for happy hour and a quick bite to eat. Good location with outdoor seating and a good vibe inside.
author: Zi-on C.

description: Reading all the 4 star reviews we went to archive for dinner. The drinks were good - beer selection is solid and sangria was well made. But the main event -- pizza -- was terribly disappointing.  When I pay $18 for a smallish pizza pie, I expect it to be good. I mean Delfina good (ok there is no such thing, Delfina is the best)ok, La Nebbia good or at least beretta good. Nope. The crust sucked and the rest of the pizza was mediocre. It's not even farina good and that's as far as I'm willing to go when I pay $15+ for a pie. Won't be returning. Do yourself a favor and visit zero zero instead which is a few blocks from there and definitely worth the hike for a better pizza.
author: Hema P.

description:
I've stayed in this area a few times when visiting SF, but only on this most recent trip was I privy to the deliciousness being pushed out of Archive just around the corner...

On a drizzly night, a group of five of us were in need of some comforting carbs after a night of partying, and seeking a calmer environment to enjoy them in. Archive was just the ticket. A friendly man, who I can only assume is the owner/manager, greeted us at the door and immediately accommodated our group in their quaint indoor seating area - no wait on a Wednesday night. Shortly after squeezing us in, they expanded our table to more comfortably seat us and never once rushed us out or gave us any side-eye when we settled in for 2+ hours to chat and catch up. 

Their house pizzas listed on the menu will give your decision making skills a run for their money since they all sound so enticing. Truffle mushrooms? Yes, please. My girl Trish threw some roasted onions on hers like a boss, I suggest doing that. I settled on the house pepperoni, which I only had the self control to stop eating after I looked down at only two slices left (all else eaten by moi.) Que embarrassing. 

The cider they serve on tap out of Portland is really great, the cheese plate was legit and plenty to share among the group. It was served with fig spread, honey, and gluten free crackers for our intolerant friends - something the friendly boss man picked up on without us even asking. 

From now on, Archive will be on my list of musts when visiting the Bay Area.
author: Gloria C.

description:
My favorite's the Hearst pizza: mushrooms, goat cheese, truffle oil, bacon... yum! Service is friendly and efficient. Lucas is great, too. 

Sometimes the balance of ingredients is inconsistent (I think the pourer must have fallen out of the truffle oil one time, because it was so rich and oily I couldn't eat it), but usually it's awesome. Sized to split with a lunch date-- add a salad if you're hungry or need more variety/texture in your meal, but I usually don't need it. 

Archive is new enough that you can still find a table without waiting more than 5-10 mins (or no wait, if you arrive just before the lunch rush at noon), but parties larger than two may have to wait longer for one of the larger tables. 

Overall, solid food and service without an over-complicated menu. I'm lucky and cursed this place is so close to my office!

UPDATE: having been back several times since I wrote this review (by myself and with a lunch date), I'd (regretfully) steer clear of pizza IF you are in a time-sensitive situation. Twice in the last month it took about 40 minutes from ordering to reaching the table, leaving not much time to eat and enjoy before your next meeting. But the salads and sandwiches are solid alternatives, so at least there's that. 

My guess is a lot if people are ordering them now so the queue for limited oven space is longer than it used to be. On a relaxing lunch where you have time to linger, not a big deal. But when you only have an hour, it can be stressful to watch the clock and worry if you'll get back on time.
author: Krista L.

description:
4 stars for the food (I have previously had lunch here).  -3 stars for the rude hostess I just spoke to (6/25/15, 3:45 pm PDT).  I called to make a reservation at the recommendation of other Yelpers.  I assumed the Yelp information re. no reservations was incorrect (hard to believe, but inaccurate info does show up, from time to time).

FYI, Yelpers - they do not take reservations.  Repeat - they DO NOT TAKE RESERVATIONS.

Me (innocently): "Oh, really?"
... pause ...
She (annoyed): "No."
... silence ...
Me (feeling dumb): "Oh, ok."
... click ...

The end.
author: Mari I.

description:
I came in with a group of 7 for a power lunch. We came in at about 1pm and were able to be seated quickly. Since we were all there to chat, bond, hang out, we decided to get multiple things to share.

Pizzas:
All of the pizzas had a good sauce/topping ratio, crispy crust, and really some unique flavors.

Mushroom & Bacon - with a little bit of truffle oil, this might of been my favorite.

Pepperoni - I usually don't do pepperoni, but this one was good. Nothing really spectacular about it, but it was good.

Veggie Pizza - had some arugula (I think?) not my favorite.

Four Cheese - blend of local cheeses, not sure exactly what, but there was goat cheese in there. Really liked this one. Really liked the fact that my coworker didn't like goat cheese since that meant I was able to get some extra slices.

We also shared some sandwiches: A chicken sandwich and a BBQ sandwich. Both were really good!


The decor of the place is best described as upscale Southern. They serve cocktails in mason jars, exposed brick walls, wooden tables, a couple of TVs, all the seats are metal and exposed light bulbs without covers. 

Great spot to come with a group, grab some drinks and grab some bites. Didn't have any cocktails, but a co-worker did and said it was delicious. I could easily see this place packed during happy hour.
author: Blue A.

description: Top! Amazing vibe and great service. Really good cocktails and music in the background is right!
author: Rabea A.

description:
Really really impressed with the staff and the service at Archive.
Came in during lunch without calling ahead with a party of 9. They were able to seat us quickly (and we were't too cramped either - the place is pretty small!). 

We ordered the Hearst pizza to start off with (goat cheese, garlic, etc) and it was absolutely delicious.

For my dish I split the baby kale salad and drake pizza with a friend. The salad was super tangy and fresh - those peaches were insanely delicious. The drake had a really nice slightly spicy flavor from the pepper flakes. 

Overall it was a great experience - the manager even came to talk with us and gave us the recipe to the pizza crust (someone in our party wanted to know!).

Super friendly, great atmosphere, great food - would definitely go back!
author: Suzannah S.

description:
One of my new favorite lunch spots in the neighborhood and I'm looking forward to going to trying their happy hour. 

Pros:
- I went on a Monday; not sure if it's always like this but it wasn't very crowded so it was easy to get a table. Even at 12:30, there were a number of open seats.
- Great pizzas. We shared the pepperoni and the mushroom / truffle oil ones - both were delicious. The right order is probably one pizza and one salad but my lunch partner wasn't feeling salad that day. Pizzas are a good size. 
- Service was fast. We were in and out in about 45 minutes (and that included trying to flag someone down for the check for a little bit).

Cons:
- On the pricier side for lunch (~$15 per person)
author: Wendy L.

description:
Flash fried piquillo peppers with an aioli dipping sauce - The peppers were a little smaller than I expected and were rather limp versus crispy. Either way, the peppers were delicious with some being extremely spicy to others that were very mild.

The pizza was a decent size to share among two people. The crust was absolutely delectable - nicely crisp yet still retained a good chew. The menu is rather limited a few apps, salads, and pizza options with a decent cocktail menu.
author: Julia K.

description: Came here at 7 on a weeknight (note: closed on weekends!) and was able to find a seat immediately. The waitress and server were very friendly and attentive. We ordered the sangria, bruschetta, and margarita pizza. The sangria was decorated cutely (wish I took a picture) but tasted a little too much like watered down juice. I couldn't really taste the alcohol. The other cocktails on the menu sound very good so I'd definitely come back to try those. The bruschetta and pizza were very good. The bruschetta was crispy and had the right amount of tomatoes. The margarita pizza was comparable to other good pizza places. Personally, I wish the dough was a bit crispier but that's just me. Overall, I really liked this place and would come back again for happy hour.
author: Krishna S.

description:
I came here for lunch recently and the meal was excellent.  Working downtown in the financial district I found the food, atmosphere and overall service great.  I would recommend the pizza 'Classico' or the chicken salad.  The portions are generous and I believe my associate and I were in and back at work with-in the hour.
Price wise I would say the dishes range between $8-$15 dollars.  With the pizza and chicken salad I was out the door around $25 dollars with tip.  Great Place!
author: Chris P.

description:
A group of co-workers and I came here for drinks and dinner.  Everyone loved how close it was to bart (1 block away) and extremely easy to find.  We were blown away by the ambiance, service, drinks, and food.  The restaurant was full but not overcrowded that we couldn't get a table.  We loved the exposed brick wall, comfortable tables, and clean restroom.  
Once seated we decided to order the social board to start, which was plenty to serve our 8 person group.  The array of cheese, meats, olives, pickles, nuts and bread selections were a very nice way to start the evening.  They even make their own pickles in house!  So tasty and amazing.  We then tried a few salads which we shared family style.  They were all extremely fresh and full of flavor.  We then moved on to the pizzas; Hearst and Garcia.  Both pizzas were unique and dynamic in their own ways.  You can truly tell each dish is well thought out and that they utilize fresh ingredients.  
Throughout the whole meal we had a great time trying the creative house cocktails.  I think the groups favorite was the Watermelon Fog!  
I will definitely be back with family and friends and will hopefully utilize their happy hour!
author: Stacey C.

description:
So wish I had a pair of noise-canceling headphones with me when I dined here.

I shouldn't be surprised. 8pm, Friday night, FiDi / Soma - San Franciscans are ready to let loose for the weekend. So I get it, the noise level was just unbearable though. Forget having a conversation. The two-top tables are smooshed so close together, it was nearly impossible to get out from the table and avoid spilling your neighbor's water glass.

On to the food. We had the meatballs and Hearst pizza. Meatballs were so-so, I thought they had a funny taste to them and were pretty dry. The pizza was tasty, but pancetta tends to make things better. Service was subpar. They were busy, yes, but it took far longer than it should have to get water, the check, etc. 

This was a miss for me...I'd give it another try, but probably not for dinner. The crowd / noise combo were too much.
author: Brianna M.

description:
Nice spot for happy hour.  Two dollars off the tap, which means four bucks for a beer.  When I went there, they had a limited selection, but it was good stuff like Lagunitas and Dechutes among others.

There's also a great pizza deal during HH.  It wasn't too crowded, which is a good thing as I hate fighting for the bartender's attention up in the front.  There's also a wait staff and they're very nice.

The inside is dim, but it had a nice divy feel without looking too rundown.  I'll be here again for HH
author: Andy V.

description:
I walk by this place every single day and I just had to stop in. I loved the ambiance, though it does get a little noisy because of the music. Still..was super cute and fun. They had a good selection of wine and beer..and mostly pizza on the menu.

The bartender, Kevin, he was an extremely nice man. Very friendly and provided great service. He also seemed to be able to read my mind when I saw a pizza float on by.. hehehe..or maybe my face is just that animated.

It isn't super large, but I could definitely see it being a nice place to stop in for a quick bite with friends or just a place to meet up and grab a few drinks.

Super convenient location and will have to drag all my coworkers out here at some point in the near future! :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This is my favorite pizza spot in the city.

Not only are the pizzas tasty (the Hearst is super yummy!) but the cocktails are EXCELLENT. The Imperial Orange, the Archive Buck, and the alcoholic root beer float (I KNOW DREAM COME TRUE) are some favorites.

Waitstaff is super professional and friendly, they seem like a big family. And the twine-wrapped napkins are a nice touch!
author: Linda W.

description:
Solid lunch spot - Salad, pizza and sandwiches - if you're in the area.

HappY Dining....
author: Nader A.

description: Great place for happy hour after work! I've been several times and the manager always makes you feel welcome right away. I've never had to wait for a table longer than 8-10 minutes. Sitting outside on a nice day is always refreshing if you've been sitting inside all day at work. And sitting inside is cozy and warm if it's a chilly day. Great atmosphere overall. I recommend getting the Hearst pizza and wine! :) YUM!
author: McKenzie D.

description: The food was good, not great, but good.  I loved this place mostly due to its laid-back vibe and motown music.   I would definitely go back.
author: Kelly M.

description:
First time here I came with my friend after work. It was busy when we got there( always a good sign) but we didn't have to wait long to get a seat. We had the kale salad and the mushroom truffle pizza, both equally delicious. I'm a big fan of kale salads and this one definitely brought pleasure to my tastebuds. Fresh nectarines, amazing cheese, it was an all around win. The pizza was awesome; great crust, and it was just the right size for sharing. Just about all the drinks looked like they would be tasty. Of the 3 I had last night, I truly loved the watermelon fog and the one with fresh cucumber juice( sorry forgot the name). Both drinks were super refreshing and yummy! 

Loved the small intimate environment and the service was great. A part of me wishes I worked on SF and could go more often.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: Honestly, the food is good but not something special. The portions are dissent but again not the American standards. The service was very unprofessional though. We were continuously asked if we want to pay the bill. We also requested some tab water twice which never arrived.
author: Anastasis A.

description: What a great little find! We went for happy hour and enjoyed a delicious piping hot pizza and wine. This cozy little place was packed with locals getting off work. We were greeted warmly and while the place is small it was charming and filled up rapidly. The food was fresh, savory, and the service good. We will be back!
author: Louise Y.

description:
A little more on the expensive side but the food is worth it! Highly recommend one of the pizzas. Drinks are fairly good as well but may not be worth the price.

Great ambience and the waiters are super friendly, they would check in several times during the course of the meal.
author: Ashwin M.

description:
Really enjoyed happy hour at Archive! We waited next door at Atlas for a table and when the table was ready the owner came and found us inside Atlas and told us our table was ready (later we found out hes the owner of both restaurants).  We really appreciated him going out of his way to get us our table! 

I forget our waiters name but I believe it was Esteban.  He was amazing! Cracking jokes, talking with us, it really made for a fun happy hour.  

The food was great. We got two pizzas the DiMaggio which was really yummy and the Hearst.  I am not a fan of truffle oil but it was still pretty tasty! The beers were great and had such a great variety of craft beers!

I appreciated the great service from our waiter! I will be back for another happy hour!

PS. Ask to try the hot sauces - Mango Tango is BOMB!
author: Brittany N.

description: Place has great food, servers and bartenders are really good. Great beers as well. Awesome place to go for lunch, only issue is that it is small and could get crowded/packed. A little expensive but where in SF isn't?! Check this place out!
author: Jeff C.

description: Great little gem on the SOMA side of the financial district. I love coming here for lunch with coworkers to get sandwiches, pizza, salads, and of course, wine. The bartenders/servers are all wonderful and make sure you're taken care of. The food is good and generally comes out pretty quickly. It's definitely on the pricer side but so is everything in San Francisco.
author: Sarah H.

description: Excellent appetizers. I also suggest the "Local" tap ale.
author: Doug S.

description:
Came for a birthday lunch with my work team around 11am - wasn't crowded and we were pleased!

Pluses - delicious pizza, salads are fresh as well, huge variety of drinks, great service, good price point, good size portions

Minuses - can't think of any?
author: Grace Y.

description:
Was expecting much much better.  Arrived at 11AM, not a soul in the place, but they still tried to stick us at the smallest possible table.  The service was unremarkable, flat and downright rude.  While the decor was fine, they are trying way to hard to be hipster cool.  Not cool.

While the pizza was good, the menu was limited.  Highlight was the Caesar salad.

Definitely not worth the price.
author: Marc R.

description: #SocietyMomsFavorite * a restaurant frequented by Darling Bonnie's Mom + Fairy God Mother * Go on a weekday during lunch x sit at the bar x order rosé + the shrimp salad sandwich w/ a side of mixed greens x ask for Matthew, he's the cute guy behind the bar w/ the handle bar mustache * if he isn't there.... Leave. Haha just kidding !
author: Ashley B.

description:
There's a slightly buttoned-up vibe at Archive but that shouldn't come as any surprise due to the location. If I were a banker/lawyer type looking for a local spot for a good lunch/late day drink.* Since I have left those suits to hang in my guest bedroom closet, I'll just plan on coming here for a good lunch/midday drink.**

Since you're, likely, here with a group o' folks, go for the pizza. The pizza here's really good, easily shared and comes with an interesting variety of toppings. Whilst gorging, I sampled the Hearst (truffle oil, goat cheese, mushrooms, & bacon: delicious; I'd order again), Moscone (sausage, pepperoni and black olives: tasty but nothing too out of the ordinary), Garcia (speck, asparagus, arugula, garlic oil &, an egg: egg on pizza = always good), and the Drake (kale, cherry tomatoes, sauteed onions, Calabrian chili, goat cheese, & cheese cream sauce: fantastic, fancy and delicious). Because I'm a fatty and was eating with other fatties, I also sampled the pulled pork sandwich (bbq sauce and jalapeno-cilantro slaw: a mighty tasty sandwich). To cut all the fatty food, I enjoyed a refreshing hibiscus/hum beverage. Four years after first having hum, I still have zero idea what the h it is -- other than refreshing & sweet... plus, it's made from hibiscus so that means it's totally healthy and will add another 80 years to my life. That's how it works.

*I would say 'after work' but we both know you're not getting out of the office any time before 7/8 if you're big firm'ing it these days.
**Much better.
author: Johnny T.

description: Seriously the absolute best place around! I highly recommend their cheese board with some red wine. Gluten free friendly too!
author: Meghan L.

description: Pork belly slider. So delicious. $4 during HH. Melted soft porky fat vs. crisp apple and sweet jam with parsley are to die for. Almost as good as Ferry Building Farmers Market Roli Roti porchetta sandwich. Evokes similar tastes and sense of indulgence.
author: Alias A.

description:
A solid 3.5 stars.  It's good, not amazing.

Our server was really friendly, which almost made me boost this review up to 4 stars, but the more I thought about it, the food was just not THAT good. 

We tried the Baby Kale Salad and the Moscone Pizza (Sausage, Pepperoni, Black Olives, Mozzarella and Tomato Sauce).  I guess I am spoiled by the pizza at Pizzeria Delfina, so my standards are a little high, but the pizza at Archive did not blow me away.  Don't get me wrong, it was definitely good, but it's pretty hard for pizza to be bad.  Even when pizza is bad, it's good (i.e. Round Table).

All in all, I will definitely give this place another try or two, maybe for their sandwiches, but I'm in no hurry.
author: Juliana K.

description: The wine list wasn't great but I found an ok white. I did however notice that the beer options were pretty good and the pizza looked tempting (they have a gf option!). The setting was also decidedly low key for a spot in downtown SF, allowing a friend and I the opportunity to catch up without having to yell over tons of noise at each other.
author: Erin W.

description:
Pizza was very good. Space was cramped. Since they don't take reservations, it's a crapshoot for where you'll be sitting. We ended up at the bar without having to wait too long even though the place was very busy and it was raining.. The space/atmosphere is nice. It's themed well.

The food was good.
author: Courtney W.

description: The pizza and salad combo we ordered here was really great, so great that I have a feeling no matter what else you order on the menu--it's going to be good! Throughout the night I was seeing apps float by that looked really really good. I also like that this place has outdoor and indoor seating.
author: Justin B.

description: Good pizza, but not great.
author: Ada C.

description:
really really good. Went here with my mom last night for happy hour and I was really impressed!

Happy hour (i think) is $3 off draft beers, $5 hour wine, and $2 off pizzas. They also had a rose sangria for happy hour last night that was delicious-- not too sweet. We ordered a delicious pizza with kale, cherry tomatoes, chili flakes, and goat cheese (my fave)-- it was amazing!! The service was great too, not overbearing, not ignoring us-- despite the big crowd for happy hour. I just wish this place was closer to my house or my office-- I would definitely be a regular!

I will definitely be back!
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I will never think of pizza the same way again. 

Went with the Hearst, it was phenomenal. Truffle oil, feta cheese, bacon (not the crappy kind u get at the grocery store, this was like butcher's cut bacon), mushrooms, whole roasted garlic cloves (if you've never had a roasted clove of garlic, you don't know what you're missing). one pizza was enough to get 2 of us full.

also ordered a drink - "Bay Lights," which was just as amazing. To be honest, it was like an upgraded mojito- but i loveee mojitos. 

you can also ask to upgrade the crust to gluten-free, which we did, and it was still really good.
author: Alana V.

description: I came on a weekday right at noon and sat at the bar. The bartender immediately waited on me. I ordered a Crispin cider and the Archive Club sandwich. The sandwich was great with fresh ingredients. Service is the highlight of this place and I was able to get in and out quickly during the lunch rush.
author: Katherine F.

description:
Really like this place. Cute / hip vibe, really nice pizza and cocktails. Service was great, even during a busy happy hour. 

Only thing that could be improved is some work on sound proofing / acoustics. Can be reaaaally loud (hard to hear the people next to you) in such a tight space when full.
author: A H.

description: Legit, I eat here about once a week. My co-workers and I walk in and sit down, even at lunch time. The service is fantastic, the place is clean and the decor is cool and comforting. I'm going to wrap this up by saying, The Hearst...Visit and figure it out.
author: P F.

description:
My favorite thin crust pizza place to date! I'm not too big of a fan of thin crust but this place has made me second guess that.

I came here with a few coworkers during lunch and were seated immediately. We ordered two pizzas and a salad:

Garcia Pizza ($16) - Arugula, parmesean and mozzarella cheese, garlic oil, asparagus, and FRESH FARM EGG. Can't hate an egg on a pizza. The egg was cooked to perfect medium so it wasn't oozey and gushy all over the pizza that would've made it messy to eat. And I hate arugula but I could barely notice it.

Hearst Pizza ($15) - MY FAVE. White truffle oil, mushrooms, bacon, goat and mozzarella cheese. I went crazy over this pizza and it was all I really ate. I love truffle oil because it gives an extra distinguishable flavor to every dish. Did I also mention that I love mushrooms? And who hates bacon? There was a lot of delectable flavors going on in this pizza.

Chicories ($11) - Choices, Gorgonzola, apples, toasted almonds with a honey-lemon vinaigrette. I don't eat salad nor do I like it but if I must eat then I will choose the salad that has the most sweets and a vinaigrette dressing to mask the taste of the leaves and this salad did just that. Good but nothing special or out of the ordinary. You can add chicken for $3 extra if you like.

The pizzas are a bit on the smaller size but when it tastes this good I don't feel like I'm getting jipped. The crust was soft yet crunchy at the same time and that's hard to do. Our server was attentive and was always there to refill our waters without asking and came to check up on us often. This place DEFINITELY beats Zero Zero and I will certainly be back.
author: Kristina D.

description:
Stumbled upon this place via yelp, kind of new to the area. We arrived in time for HH and ordered a few glasses of wine and the Hearst pizza. The house cab was prettty good and oh my the pizza was yummy. Kind of ruin my diet, but darn well worth it!!! The feta cheese really tied in the flavor well and the size was good enough for 2-3 people. I believe all pizza were $2 off and wine was like $5 or $6 for HH.

Matt was an awesome bartender!
author: Nhung T.

description: Went here for dinner based on yelp reviews. The pizza was okay a little to much garlic also got the spinach and artichoke dip it can with 5 tiny slices of bread we had half the dip left and nothing to dip it in. It was super tasty but there wasn't enough bread! My rating is based on taste so if you are a couple looking for a tiny pizza and some appetizers for 50 bucks or less then this is the place
author: Jamie H.

description:
Food, drinks, service.. AWESOME! But damn, I can't hear in here!! LOL Pizza's we had, was really good. We had different kinds, I can't really remember, but I can't think of one that I didn't like.  Also their Sliders, was heaven in my mouth. SERIOUSLY!! I love me some pork belly. LOL Heart attack/ Gout city, but worth it! 

The only drink I had all night was the Archive Cocktail, which was the best. I think I got the name wrong, but it was delish, to where I didn't care for the other drinks. Definitely coming back here again and taking other friends for drinks here.
author: Joanne D.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered a small salad.  It was pretty big for a small salad and tasty.  My gf ordered a gluten free pizza, which looked delicious.  The space is clean and the staff is very friendly and check in often.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Negar A.

description:
This was hands-down one of the best dining experiences I've had in a long time--especially since going wheat-free.

Five of us friends were in town for a big conference, and we desperately needed a low-key evening away where we could catch up and eat our hearts out. Thank Gaga for Archive...

When we walked up, the nicest guy was at the door to greet us (I'm pretty sure he was either the owner or the manager). They quickly seated us and sent over a super-friendly server who could not have been lovelier. I explained this wheat-free nonsense to her, and she didn't bat an eyelash. She told me they had wheat-free pizzas! Yippee!

Before our pizzas came out, we got a cheese board that was filled with some tasty treats--no blue cheese (hooray!) and wheat-free crackers! Oh, it's always the little things. And then our pizzas came out... delicious! I couldn't have been happier with my 5-cheese pizza. For a little while, I completely forgot that I couldn't eat like I used to. 

During our amazing dinner, we stayed and laughed and gabbed for over two hours, and not once did the staff make us feel rushed. In fact, they pushed another table over so that we'd have more room to spread out! The guy from earlier also came out to let us try a gluten-free beer he was considering for the menu. Talk about hospitality...

I wish we had a place like this back home in Columbus, but I'll just anxiously await my next trip to SF so I can head back over to Archive.
author: Bryant M.

description:
Really fun and great location! But left deaf. It was so so loud hence 3 stars vs 5.

We ordered the burrata, honey, apple, proscuitto appetizer which was really good, champagne, beer, sangria during the happy hour. Menu seemed excellent. I'd go back but sit outside.
author: Karen M.

description:
The pickles were surprisingly good.  Pizza was okay.  Flavorful toppings, sauce and bread, but the middle of the pizza was a tad soggy.

$5 Happy hour wine and $2 off Pizza before 6pm.  

Can't wait til they expand.
author: Mihae T.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place out after walking past it after work for 3 months. The inside is decorated very nicely. Hip and modern, but still comfortable and welcoming. The staff are very friendly and accommodating with my requests (no cheeses except mozzarella please). 

There are only about 10 tables (outside included) plus the bar area so it gets PACKED at lunch. Come before 11:45pm to guarantee a table. 

I highly recommend the Fall Harvest pizza (butternut squash, piquillo peppers, pumpkin seeds, arugula, goat cheese, mozzarella, tomato sauce). The combination is perfect with a few shakes of pepper flakes (beware- super spicy!). 

It seems to be crackin' during happy hour too so I'm definitely coming back some time to try their drinks out.
author: Sophia V.

description:
Came here around 5pm for Happy Hour.  My friend and I sat at the bar.  The decor was pretty cool and hip.  We ordered two drinks and a pizza to share.  Unfortunately the bartender spilled the whole drink over on me.  My dress, my boots, and bag were all wet...........unbelievable.....

We supposed to order a veggie pizza but the bartender gave us a pepperroni pizza.  He said the pizza was from the house because of the apology.  Seriously I would rather to have two free drinks better than an extra pizza, because how could two people finish two pizzas?  

About 15 minutes later, we saw our veggie pizza at the next table.  The man told the waiter that was not the pizza they ordered......and he gave the pizza back to us.  Now I don't really know the free pizza was just from the house or they just messed up the order.  It seemed like they were not organized back in the kitchen.

When we looked at the bill, they forgot to take out $2.00 from the pizza because all pizzas were half off during HH.....

Overall, the pizza was good.  The ingredient was fresh and tasty but the service was not that good.
author: Liza T.

description:
So perfect for a quick drink after work in the FiDi or a quiet date night. Super casual, great beer choices and PIZZA! 

The service was also really great and the bartender was really friendly. It got more crowded towards 630/7pm, but a happy medjum (which is hard to find).

Will be back again soon!
author: Amanda U.

description:
Archive is a dimly-lit, trendy restaurant-bar hybrid, tucked away right next to downtown SF. I did not expect much going because of the low number of reviews, but I was very impressed. I came on a Friday night with a friend and there were spots open at the bar.

- Prosciutto/Burrata Plate (~$13): I'm not sure what this was called or what the price was, but it was in the appetizer section. It comes on a wooden slab, with freshly cut prosciutto (you can see the prosciutto rolls in the back near the restrooms), burrata, cornichons, toasted almonds, and 4 pieces of toast. The quality of ingredients and flavor combination is on-point.

- Hearst Pizza ($15): The Hearst comes with truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, wild mushrooms, and pancetta. The pizza was a bit smaller than I envisioned, but they load it with toppings and the dough is the perfect fluffiness. The mushrooms, in particular, were very flavorful.

- Spring Sangria ($8/glass): This is a pretty small glass with a lot of ice, but the wine is pretty high quality. The strawberry-passion fruit puree did not overpower the natural flavor of the wine.

If you're looking for a casual dinner with good drinks, Archive is a good choice!
author: Jessica F.

description:
Archive is a great spot close to work. It may seem small and unassuming from the outside when passing by, but they serve some awesome food!

Most recently, I ordered the Hearst pizza which consists of white truffle oil, goat cheese, fresh mozzarella, mushrooms, bacon, and tons of roasted garlic!!! It's definitely a pizza that's all about that umami goodness. Together, all those ingredients taste delicious. Definitely a fan of the conservative use of the white truffle oil. There are way too many places that are too heavy-handed with it and just ruin their dishes.

Previously, they had a pizza with bacon, radicchio, and figs. Also delicious. You really can't go wrong with any the pizzas. The pizzas are probably a bit larger than individual-sized, but it's not quite enough food for 2 people.

P.S. They also have ginger beer!
author: Vivian L.

description: My boyfriend and I are visiting from out of town and our hotel was close by so we figured why not. We ordered the DiMaggio pizza and the meatball sandwich. The pizza was beyond delicious! The flavors were amazing. The meatball sandwich, although it doesn't look like much, the flavors were also very good. I'm only giving it 4 stars because we went at 2:00pm when we were the only people there, so the service was great. Definitely going back before we head home.
author: Erica C.

description:
Today I was calling 3 times and 3 times I was speaking with guy name kiven . He was very rude. I wont  to order pizza with olive. He said that they don't have and hang the phone on my face. 
I am very week ordering the same thing .(  Playing little head .)
author: Tuli B.

description:
I'm pretty happy about Archive Bar. My wife and I wandered in here on a busy Friday evening and were shown right to a table; no fuss, no wait. The staff was friendly, the beer selection was good (though a bit limited), and they have an interesting cocktails list.

The Chicken Alfredo pizza was very tasty, not overly cheesy or dry (the way that sort of topping-heavy pizza sometimes gets). And the jar of proper dill pickles for a side was delicious.

Ambience was fun and lively, happy hour was a good deal, and the decor was pretty interesting. We'll definitely be back.
author: Alex L.

description:
There aren't many bar/restaurant that are open for lunch in SOMA. I'm really happy that this cool restaurant is so close to home!

Came here for lunch with a friend and my husband on a week day. It was packed but we got seats at the bar. The menu is pretty simple comprised of pizza or sandwiches. I had to try their pizza and both my husband + friend went for the pulled pork sandwich with cocktails.

The pizza took a bit longer as they had to make it with each order but it was really good! I couldn't finish it alone because it was quite big. The crust was thin and toppings were flavorful just the way I like it! I didn't try the pulled pork sandwich but it looked good and came with side of potato chips. The prices were not too high (surprisingly for SOMA and so close to FiDi). 

Cool place for lunch or if you want to have a cocktail in the middle of the day!
author: Vickie Z.

description: The best Manhattan in the Bay Area, it's called Tone Bennett Manhattan, made by Cameron the bartender.
author: Antonio V.

description: Not a bad place for hh and dinner with the girls before I leave the city. The slider was tasty and i liked the hearst pizza.
author: Annie W.

description: I think it's safe to say archive bar is officially in the archives.... Wow... I had such high expectations for this place, now I must find another bar to go to. I'm usually light weight when it comes to my drinks and... Guess what?! The drinks we had today was way watered down... Paying $8 & tips for watered down drinks? No thank you.. I can get that for $5 elsewhere.. However, service was acceptable... But the drinks seriously?!! They tasted like nonalcoholic drinks..
author: Ann L.

description: First time I've eaten here, it was busy so the service was a tad slow but the mixed green salad I had with chicken was pretty amazing. All the flavors together just worked.
author: Shelley H.

description: Archive is a great addition to SoMa. They did a fantastic job with the decor. Absolutely love the exposed brick wall and old file cabinets. Went here for beers and a bite after work. It was perfect. Not too loud but not to quiet either. Beers on tap are good. We had a pizza. We tried the truffle one which didn't say on the menu that it had garlic. In my opinion it was too much whole garlic. It overwhelmed the rest of the ingredients. My friend on the other hand was eating my garlic cloves out of my hand. I'll definitely be back here to try another pizza and enjoy the ambiance.
author: Kelly C.

description: After an amazing session at Soul Cycle, I met up with a friend to undo all of our hard work. We stumbled upon Archive as we were headed elsewhere and were drawn in by the smell of the pizzas! We had a delicious drink called a Watermelon Fog with Agave Wine, Fresh Watermelon Juice, Fino Sherry & Sea Salt-Lime Air. That's right, sea salt lime air. There was a big pile of flavored foam on top. It was so much fun. We shared a Hearst pizza with goat cheese and truffle oil and an appetizer of brussel sprouts. So delicious!
author: Kari G.

description: We were lucky enough to find a spot at the bar, thanks to the amazing staff. The mac&cheese was fabulous, as was the wine selection. As a plus, the SF chase scene from Bullitt was playing on the TV. Great atmosphere. Awesome staff. :) Thanks for having us!
author: Lisa H.

description:
I can't say it was bad but it wasn't anything special. Pizzas were tasty if not a little over priced. The apps were good - liked the beet salad and the orzo mac and cheese was yummy but also over priced ($9 I think).  Service was marginal, walked in at 9pm (1 hour before closing) and kind of got the feeling they were not keen to serve us but we were a group of 6 so I don't know why they'd be like that. There were only seats at the bar left because they had taken up two tables with some napkins and utensils they were rolling together - I thought it was surprising that they didn't offer us the tables so eventually I just got up the courage to ask since it seemed ridiculous that they'd take over tables that could be seating people. 

The drinks were pretty good - I will say that the bar tender seemed pretty skilled. Overall Archive was just OK.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
A friend and I decided to visit Archive after having a drink at Novela. 

The place was pretty full with almost every patron enjoying the pizza. We found some space at the end of the bar and received attention immediately. The server handed us menus and was right on point to come back and take our drink and food orders.

We both had a glass of wine - quite generously poured into a stemless glass. For food, we shared the Prosciutto & Burrata appetizer and Moscone pizza.
